{{Unreferenced|date=March 2009}} {{Infobox book | name = Nothing's Sacred | image = NothingsSacred.jpg | author = [[Lewis Black]] | editor = Hank Gallo | publisher = Simon Spotlight Entertainment | release_date = 2005 (Hardcover)
2006 (Paperback, Audiobook) | media_type = | pages = 217 | size_weight = | isbn = }} '''''Nothing's Sacred''''' is the [[autobiography]] of comedian [[Lewis Black]]. It was published in 2005, and republished in 2006 (paperback edition). The 2006 publication contains new material and one of the plays he wrote during his career as a [[playwright]]. The book has also been released in unabridged audio CD format, narrated by Black himself. The book is narrated in the same fashion as Black's [[stand-up comedy|stand-up]] routines, with explicit language, [[sarcasm]], and constant fits of [[rage (emotion)|rage]]. The book primarily accounts Lewis' admiration for his seemingly eccentric family, his disregard for authority, his education, past habitual drug use, his perspectives on current issues, and other real-life events such as his [[hitchhiking]] trip in Europe or his late pet dog, John-John. The book's layout is in semi-chronological order. The book has no [[table of contents]] and a lengthy page of acknowledgments. == Excerpts from the book == *"So many leaves, so little time. I will buy a leaf blower." *"If there is a hell, it is modeled after Jr. High." *"Just the memory of it makes me want to go to the bathroom." *"I was lucky to have an animal like that as my owner." *"Somehow, psychopaths always get service." *"We are passing on a legacy of shit." *"One doesn't shit in a [[bidet]], because one has to clean it up." *"If [[United States Postal Service|The Post Office]] didn't already exist, [[Franz Kafka|Kafka]] would've invented it." ==See also== *[[The Parts That Were Left Out of the Kennedy Book]] [[Category:2005 books]] [[Category:Comedy books]] [[Category:Show business memoirs]]

{{Use American English|date=July 2015}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Pan | image = Pan 2015 poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Joe Wright]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * [[Greg Berlanti]] * Sarah Schechter * [[Paul Webster (producer)|Paul Webster]] }} | writer = [[Jason Fuchs]] | based on = {{based on|''[[Peter Pan]]''|[[J. M. Barrie]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Levi Miller]] * [[Hugh Jackman]] * [[Garrett Hedlund]] * [[Rooney Mara]] * [[Adeel Akhtar]] * [[Kathy Burke]] * [[Nonso Anozie]] * [[Amanda Seyfried]] }} | music = [[John Powell (film composer)|John Powell]] | cinematography = {{Plainlist| * [[Seamus McGarvey]] * [[John Mathieson (cinematographer)|John Mathieson]] }} | editing = {{Plainlist| * Paul Tothill * [[William Hoy]] }} | production companies = Berlanti Productions
RatPac Entertainment{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/pan-film-review-824864|title='Pan': Film Review|last=McCarthy|first=Todd|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=September 19, 2015|accessdate=June 1, 2017}} | distributor = [[Warner Bros.|Warner Bros. Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2015|09|20|[[London]]{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/News_Photos/Entertainment/World-Premiere-of-Pan-in-London/9489/|title=World Premiere of 'Pan' in London - Photos|work=UPI}}|2015|10|09|United States}} | runtime = 111 minutes{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/pan-film-0 | title=''PAN'' [2D] (PG) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=September 17, 2015 | accessdate=September 17, 2015}} | country = United States{{cite web|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/56189969b230a|title=Pan (2015)|work=[[British Film Institute]]|accessdate=June 1, 2017}} | language = English | budget = $150 million{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/summer-box-office-whats-behind-790318|title=Summer Box Office: What's Behind Warner Bros.' Risky Move to Release Nine Movies|author=Pamela McClintock|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=([[Prometheus Global Media]])|date=April 21, 2015|accessdate=April 21, 2015}} | gross = $128.4 million{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=pan.htm |title=Pan (2015) |website=Box Office Mojo |accessdate=February 29, 2016}} }} '''''Pan''''' is a 2015 American [[fantasy film]]{{cite web|url=https://catalog.afi.com/Catalog/moviedetails/70601?sid=840123e4-4280-40d8-8eb9-524defa39522&sr=8.336397&cp=1&pos=0&cxt=Filmography1|title=Pan (2015)|publisher=American Film Institute|accessdate=August 7, 2018}} directed by [[Joe Wright]] and written by [[Jason Fuchs]]. The film serves as a prequel to ''[[Peter and Wendy]]'' from Scottish author [[J. M. Barrie]], which was first staged in 1904, and focuses on an alternative [[origin story]] for [[Peter Pan]] and [[Captain Hook]]. It stars [[Levi Miller]] as the title character, along with [[Hugh Jackman]], [[Garrett Hedlund]], [[Rooney Mara]], and [[Amanda Seyfried]]. ''Pan'''s world premiere was held in [[London]] on September 20, 2015,{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xTSPZa4pKMo|title=Pan – World Premiere - Official Warner Bros. UK|date=September 21, 2015|work=YouTube}} and it was theatrically released in the United States on October 9, 2015, by [[Warner Bros. Pictures]]. ''Pan'' grossed $128.4 million against a production budget of $150 million and was widely considered a [[box office bomb]], resulting in significant loss for the studio. The film received generally negative reviews, with criticism calling the plot formulaic and the action heavily-reliant on [[Computer-generated imagery|CGI]]. ==Plot== {{long plot|section|date=May 2016|reason=Per WP:FILMPLOT, this section should be 400 to 700 words. As of this note, the plot summary is 772 words.}} Newborn [[Peter Pan|Peter]] ([[Levi Miller]]), who has a mysterious [[pan flute]] pendant, is left by his mother Mary ([[Amanda Seyfried]]) on the steps of an orphanage in London, an establishment under the care of the [[Abuse|abusive]] [[Nun|Mother]] Barnabas ([[Kathy Burke]]). Several years later, during [[World War II]], upon learning that Mother Barnabas is hoarding food for herself, Peter and his best friend Nibs ([[Lewis MacDougall]]) try to steal it to distribute among themselves and the other orphans but they are caught. In the process, Peter finds a letter written by his mother, declaring her love and assuring Peter they will meet again "in this world or another". In retaliation for the boys' mischief, Mother Barnabas summons [[Air pirate|pirates]] who kidnap Peter, Nibs and several others. Nibs manages to escape but Peter does not. He is captured and taken aboard a flying pirate ship. Following an aerial battle with several [[Supermarine Spitfire|Spitfires]] the ship takes Peter to Neverland, a magical realm beyond space and time, where he is forced to become a slave laborer and mine for Pixum (crystallized Fairy Dust) on behalf of the terrible pirate [[Blackbeard]] ([[Hugh Jackman]]) who uses it to prevent himself from aging. Peter befriends another miner, named [[Captain Hook|James Hook]] ([[Garrett Hedlund]]). After insulting Blackbeard's men, Peter is forced to [[Walking the plank|walk the plank]] over the deep mine, but survives by flying. Blackbeard then tells Peter about an old prophecy involving a boy who could fly who would one day kill him, but Peter refuses to believe he is that boy. Peter joins Hook and his accomplice, [[Mr. Smee|Sam "Smee" Smiegel]] ([[Adeel Akhtar]]), stealing one of Blackbeard's flying ships and escapes into the forest. There they are found by the native chief's daughter [[Tiger Lily (Peter Pan)|Tiger Lily]] ([[Rooney Mara]]) and nearly executed but then Chief Great Little Panther ([[Jack Charles (actor)|Jack Charles]]) notices Peter's [[pan flute]] pendant, left to him by Mary, which is said to belong to their people's greatest hero, the legendary Pan. Using the Memory Tree, Tiger Lily tells Peter that many years ago when the natives and the fairies united to fight together against the pirates under Blackbeard, the Fairy Prince and the love of Blackbeard's life, Mary, fell in love, but when Blackbeard discovered them, the Prince took human form to rescue Mary. But as fairies could live in human form for only one day, the Prince sacrificed his life for Mary. Mary was then forced to hide their newborn son Peter in the other world on Earth and seek shelter in the Fairy Kingdom when she and the fairies had to retreat. As part of his half-fairy heritage, Peter has the ability to fly, but is unable to do so because of his lack of faith. Fearful of Blackbeard's punishment, Smee betrays the natives' location to him, and in the ensuing battle, Chief Great Little Panther is murdered by Blackbeard, who also reveals that he killed Peter's mother. Peter is hurt to learn that Tiger Lily had lied to Peter, telling him his mother is still alive, but she explains that he would have walked away from his destiny if he knew the truth. Peter, Hook, and Tiger Lily escape in a raft and head to the Fairy Kingdom to enlist their help in defeating the pirates. Along the way, Peter falls into the river and is nearly eaten by giant [[crocodile]]s before being rescued by the [[mermaid]]s, after which he has a vision of Blackbeard accidentally killing Mary as she defended the Fairy Kingdom from his offensive. Despondent over their chances, Hook leaves while Peter and Tiger Lily arrive at the Fairy Kingdom alone, only to be ambushed by Blackbeard who plans to use the fairies' vast amount of Pixum to live forever. Blackbeard takes Peter's pan flute pendant, which is the key to the fairy kingdom, opens their gates and launches an attack. Peter escapes and befriends one of the fairies, named [[Tinker Bell]]. Together, they rally the rest of the Neverland fairies to fight the pirates while Tiger Lily duels Blackbeard. Hook returns on the stolen ship and fights Blackbeard's right-hand man Bishop ([[Nonso Anozie]]) until the ship tips over, sending both falling to their deaths. Peter conquers his fears and flies to save Hook, while Blackbeard and his men are overpowered by the fairies. Forced into an abyss, they subsequently fall to their deaths. Smee is the sole survivor having fled during the battle. Peter then sees a vision of Mary, who reaffirms him to be Neverland's savior: Peter Pan. Shortly afterwards, Peter and Hook, now the captain of the ''Jolly Roger'', return to London to rescue Nibs and the other orphans, who become part of Peter's crew, the [[Lost Boys (Peter Pan)|Lost Boys]]. Peter and Hook reaffirm their friendship, certain that nothing will ever go wrong between them. ==Cast== {{Div col}} * [[Levi Miller]] as [[Peter Pan]]{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/levi-miller-tapped-to-play-peter-pan-in-warner-bros-pan-exclusive-1201136941/ |title=Levi Miller Tapped to Play Peter Pan in Warner Bros.' 'Pan' (EXCLUSIVE) |publisher=Variety |date=March 18, 2014 |accessdate=July 28, 2014}} * [[Hugh Jackman]] as [[Blackbeard]]{{cite web|last=Perlman |first=Jake |url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2014/01/24/hugh-jackman-peter-pan-blackbeard/ |title=Hugh Jackman to star in Joe Wright's Peter Pan movie |publisher=Insidemovies.ew.com |date=January 24, 2014 |accessdate=July 28, 2014}} * [[Garrett Hedlund]] as [[Captain Hook|James Hook]]{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/amanda-seyfried-joins-warner-bros-698768 |title=Amanda Seyfried Joins Warner Bros.' Peter Pan Adaptation |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=April 24, 2014 |accessdate=July 28, 2014}} * [[Rooney Mara]] as [[Tiger Lily (Peter Pan)|Tiger Lily]] * [[Adeel Akhtar]] as [[Mr. Smee|Sam "Smee" Smiegel]] * [[Kathy Burke]] as Mother Barnabas * [[Nonso Anozie]] as Bishop * [[Amanda Seyfried]] as Mary{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=117485 |title=Amanda Seyfried Boards Joe Wright's Pan |publisher=ComingSoon.net |date=April 24, 2014 |accessdate=July 28, 2014}} * [[Lewis MacDougall]] as Nibs * [[Jack Charles (actor)|Jack Charles]] as Chief Great Little Panther * [[Cara Delevingne]] as the [[mermaid]]s{{cite web|url=http://www.sugarscape.com/fashion/news/a1082225/cara-delevingne-pan-premiere/|title=Cara Delevingne hits the red carpet for the world premiere of PAN|author=Linds Foley|work=Sugarscape}} * [[Na Tae-joo]] as Kwahu{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/amanda-seyfried-joins-warner-bros-698768|title=Amanda Seyfried Joins Warner Bros.' Peter Pan Adaptation|accessdate=April 28, 2014|date=April 24, 2014|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|deadurl=no}} * [[Bronson Webb]] as Steps{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Levi|title=Pan Trailer|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/film/trailer/pan-new|accessdate=6 September 2015|publisher=[[Contactmusic.com]]}} * Kurt Egyiawan as Murray * [[Paul Kaye]] as Mutti Voosht * [[Emerald Fennell]] as Commander {{div col end}} ==Production== [[File:Jason Fuchs at the Pan Premiere.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Jason Fuchs]] at the film's premiere.]] The script for the film was listed on Hollywood's 2013 [[The Black List (survey)|Black List]].{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/the-black-list-announces-2013-screenplays-live-1200963352/ |title=The Black List Announces 2013 Screenplays (Complete List) |publisher=Variety |date=December 16, 2013 |accessdate=July 28, 2014}} In January 2014, [[Garrett Hedlund]] was cast as a younger version of [[Captain Hook]].{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.ca/movies/news/a546111/garrett-hedlund-to-play-captain-hook-in-peter-pan-movie.html?rss |title=Garrett Hedlund to play Captain Hook in Peter Pan movie? - Movies News - Digital Spy |publisher=Digitalspy.ca |date=January 23, 2014 |accessdate=July 28, 2014}} On January 24, 2014, Jackman was officially cast as the pirate [[Blackbeard]]. In February, a casting call was issued for the role of [[Peter Pan]],{{cite web|author=Mark Brown, arts correspondent |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/feb/10/hollywood-bosses-search-peter-pan |title=Looking for lost boys: Hollywood bosses launch search for a Peter Pan | Film |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=July 28, 2014}} which went to newcomer [[Levi Miller]] in March. In April 2014, [[Amanda Seyfried]] was cast. In August 2014, British model [[Cara Delevingne]] was chosen to play a [[mermaid]].{{cite web | url=http://www.nylon.com/articles/cara-delevingne-peter-pan-mermaid | title=omg! get a first look at cara delevingne in pan | publisher=[[Nylon (magazine)|Nylon]] | accessdate=August 6, 2014}} [[Rooney Mara]] was cast as [[Tiger Lily (Peter Pan)|Tiger Lily]],{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/tiger-lilly-warner-bros-pan-1201102262/ |title=Rooney Mara to Play Tiger Lily in Warner Bros.' 'Pan' |publisher=Variety |date=March 12, 2014 |accessdate=July 28, 2014}} causing [[Racebending|controversy]] due to her being of [[Ethnic groups in Europe|European]] ancestry, while Tiger Lily is traditionally portrayed as a [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]].{{cite web|last=Perlman |first=Jake |url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2014/03/13/rooney-mara-tiger-lily-controversy/ |title=Rooney Mara as 'Peter Pan's' Tiger Lily: A look at the controversy | PopWatch | EW.com |publisher=Popwatch.ew.com |date=March 13, 2014 |accessdate=July 28, 2014}} Also considered for the role of Tiger Lily were actresses [[Lupita Nyong'o]] and [[Adèle Exarchopoulos]].{{cite web|last1=Pickett|first1=Leah|title=Why Aren't we more upset about racism against native americans|url=http://www.dailydot.com/opinion/peter-pan-native-american-racism/|website=www.dailydot.com|accessdate=December 14, 2014}} According to critics of the casting there are very few main roles for Native American women in Hollywood, and that the choice not only took one away from a Native American actress, but also perpetuated the invisibility of Native Americans in film.{{cite book|last1=Garcia|first1=Alma|title=Contested Images: Women of Colour in Popular Culture|date=2012|publisher=AltaMira Press|location=Lanham, Md.|isbn=0759119635|page=45|url=https://webcat.mtroyal.ca/vwebv/holdingsInfo?searchId=720&recCount=15&recPointer=0&bibId=1371721|accessdate=December 14, 2014}} According to [[TheWrap]], director Joe Wright was trying to create a "very international and multi-racial" world,{{cite web | url=http://www.thewrap.com/rooney-mara-negotiations-play-tiger-lily-warner-bros-pan/ | title=Rooney Mara in Negotiations to Play Tiger Lily in Warner Bros.' 'Pan' | publisher=[[TheWrap]] | date=March 12, 2014 | accessdate=September 6, 2015}} although the majority of main characters (including the four lead actors) are white.{{cite web|last1=Baker-Whitelaw|first1=Gavia|title=This new photo of Tiger Lily is terrible PR for 'Pan'|url=http://www.dailydot.com/entertainment/rooney-mara-tiger-lily-pan/|website=www.dailydot.com|accessdate=December 14, 2014}} A petition was created in response to the casting to urge Warner Bros. studios to stop casting white actors in roles for [[people of color]].{{cite web|last1=McDonald|first1=Soraya Nadia|title=Thousands Petition Warner Bros. over Rooney Mara's casting as Tiger Lily|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2014/03/20/thousands-petition-warner-bros-over-rooney-maras-casting-as-tiger-lily/|website=www.washingtonpost.com|accessdate=December 14, 2014}} Previous portrayals of the Piccaninny tribe in ''Peter Pan'' have been criticized as [[Racism|racist]].{{cite web|last1=ICTMN Staff|title=Rooney Mara's Tiger Lily Could Not Be Less Native. That's A Problem.|url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2014/11/26/rooney-maras-tiger-lily-could-not-be-less-native-thats-problem-158028|website=www.indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com|accessdate=December 14, 2014}} Critics of the casting in ''Pan'' suggested that Warner Bros. may have wanted to avoid repeating the alleged racism of previous ''Peter Pan'' stories, by altering the ethnicity of the Piccaninnies, rather than using a stereotypical portrayal of the source material. Many also felt that native actresses and actors were never given an opportunity to make it to mainstream films, with native roles being traditionally given to non-natives.{{cite web|url=http://www.xojane.com/issues/hollywood-|title=Hollywood Wants To Cast Rooney Mara As A Native American, We Native Americans Want Hollywood To Give Us A Chance|date=March 19, 2014|publisher=}} ===Filming=== On April 28, 2014, the film's [[principal photography]] began.{{cite web|url=http://www.ssninsider.com/on-the-set-for-5514-hugh-jackman-starrer-pan-starts-for-warner-bros-new-line-cinemas-crawlspace-wraps/ |title=On The Set For 5/5/14: Hugh Jackman Starrer 'Pan' Starts For Warner Bros., New Line Cinema's 'Crawlspace' Wraps |publisher=SSN Insider |date=2014-05-05 |accessdate=2015-10-11}} Many natural scenes in the film were from [[Son Doong Cave]], [[Phong Nha-Kẻ Bàng National Park]] and [[Ninh Bình Province]] in [[Vietnam]]. The captured scenes were then graphically edited into the film. ==Soundtrack== The film's soundtrack was released in 2015. It was composed by [[John Powell (film composer)|John Powell]], and additional music by Anthony Willis, Batu Sener, Paul Mounsey. [[Dario Marianelli]], a frequent collaborator with Wright, had composed a score for the film, but Warner Bros. later replaced him with Powell after test screenings.{{cite web|last=Savas|first=Kaya|date=October 11, 2015|url=http://www.filmmusicmedia.com/reviews/panbyjohnpowellreview|title=Pan by John Powell (Review)|work=Film.Music.Media|accessdate=January 7, 2017}} ; Track list * "[[Smells Like Teen Spirit]]" – Performed by [[Hugh Jackman]] and Cast * "[[Blitzkrieg Bop]]" – Performed by [[Hugh Jackman]] and Cast * "Short Change Hero" – Performed by Capitol Children's Choir & Metro Voices * "Something's Not Right" – Performed by [[Lily Allen]] * "Little Soldier" – Performed by [[Lily Allen]] * "Irish Blessing" – Performed and Arranged by The African Children's Choir * All Music – Composed and written by John Powell ==Release== [[File:SDCC 2015 - Aisha Tyler, Joe Wright, Levi Miller, Garrett Hedlund & Hugh Jackman (19086260314).jpg|right|thumb|The cast and crew of ''Pan'' at the 2015 [[San Diego Comic-Con]] to promote the film.]] On December 12, 2013, Warner Bros. set for a June 26, 2015 release, with [[Joe Wright]] as director.{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=112440 |title=Warner Bros. Sets Joe Wright's Pan release date for June 26, 2015 |publisher=ComingSoon.net |date=December 12, 2013 |accessdate=July 28, 2014}} The release was pushed back several times,{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=113669 |title=Warner Bros. Pictures Pushes Batman vs. Superman Back to 2016 |publisher=ComingSoon.net |date=January 17, 2014 |accessdate=July 28, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.finalreel.co.uk/pan-us-release-date-pushed-back-ant-man/ |title=Warner Bros. Pushes Back Joe Wright's Pan by a Week, Shifts Out of Ant-Man's Shadow |publisher=FinalReel.co.uk |accessdate=December 12, 2014}} and the studio eventually decided on October 9, 2015, in part to avoid box office competition from summer blockbusters such as ''[[Ant-Man (film)|Ant-Man]]'' and ''[[Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation]]''.{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/pan-release-date-october-hugh-hackman-1201476156/|title=Hugh Jackman's 'Pan' Moves Back from Summer to Fall|publisher=Variety|date=April 20, 2015|accessdate=April 20, 2015}} The new release date also gave the producers more time to work on editing and visual effects during post-production.{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/hugh-jackmans-pan-moves-summer-790308|title=Hugh Jackman's 'Pan' Moves From Summer to Fall|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=April 20, 2015|accessdate=April 21, 2015}} The film was first released in Australia, on September 25, 2015. It was then released in key markets two weeks later, including Germany, Russia, Korea, and Brazil, on October 8. That was followed by Mexico and Spain the next day. The film opened in the United Kingdom on October 16, 2015, and France on October 21, 2015, followed by China on October 22, 2015, Japan on October 31, 2015, and Italy on November 12, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/09/hotel-transylvania-2-the-intern-pan-sicario-lost-in-hong-kong-box-office-international-1201553347/|title='Hotel Transylvania 2,' 'The Intern' Bow Amidst Holdovers 'Everest' And 'Scorch Trials' – Intl Box Office|author=Anita Busch|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=([[Penske Media Corporation]])|date=September 27, 2015|accessdate=September 28, 2015}} ''Pan'' was originally planned for an [[IMAX]] release, as evident in early posters, trailers, and press,{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/trailers/612919-new-pan-featurette-goes-in-depth-on-the-films-colorful-3d-worlds#/slide/50|title=New Pan Featurette Goes in Depth on the Film's Colorful 3D Worlds - ComingSoon.net|date=September 15, 2015|publisher=|accessdate=June 19, 2016}} but was cancelled and only received non-IMAX presentations. ===Home media=== ''Pan'' was released on DVD and [[Blu-ray]] on December 22, 2015, by [[Warner Home Video]], two-and-a-half months after the film's release. ''Pan'' was one of the first Ultra HD Blu-ray released on March 1, 2016. ==Reception== ===Box office=== ''Pan'' was financially unsuccessful.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/time-warner-reports-mixed-quarterly-results-due-to-movie-flops-1201702038/|title=Time Warner Reports Mixed Quarterly Results Due to Movie Flops|author=Brent Lang|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=February 10, 2016|accessdate=February 10, 2016}} It grossed $35.1 million in North America and $93.2 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $128.3 million. In comparison, its production budget was reported to be $150 million, and the total spent on marketing was estimated at $100–125 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/warner-bros-pan-could-lead-831412|title=Warner Bros.' 'Pan' Could Lead to $150 Million Loss|author=Pamela McClintock|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=([[Prometheus Global Media]])|date=October 12, 2015|accessdate=October 13, 2015}} In the United States and Canada, the film grossed $5.2 million on its opening day. In its opening weekend, the film grossed $15.3 million, below the studio's $20 million projection, and finished third at the box office.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/10/martian-pan-the-walk-weekend-box-office-1201572119/|title='Martian' Still Has Fuel In Its Second Frame; 'Pan' Walks Plank; 'Steve Jobs' Popular In NY & LA – Monday Postmortem |author=Anthony D'Alessandro|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=October 12, 2015|accessdate=October 14, 2015}} Several factors have been attributed to the financial failure of ''Pan''. ''[[Forbes]]'' blogger Scott Mendelson attributed this to the absence of notable movie stars. Despite the presence of Jackman, "like any number of would-be big stars who are best known for a certain franchise, his opening weekend strength dips when he's not playing his trademark character." Outside of the [[X-Men (film series)|''X-Men'' franchise]], his biggest openings are ''[[Van Helsing (film)|Van Helsing]]'' ($51 million) and the $27 million debuts of ''[[Real Steel]]'' and ''[[Les Misérables (2012 film)|Les Misérables]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2015/10/12/box-office-4-reasons-pan-bombed/|title=Box Office: 4 Reasons 'Pan' Bombed|author=Scott Mendelson|work=[[Forbes]]|date=October 12, 2015|accessdate=October 14, 2015}} ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' described the departure of the film in tone and writings that made earlier Peter Pan stories and films a success; from Jackman's role as [[Blackbeard]] to the inclusion of contemporary pop songs from [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]] and the [[Ramones]] which is peculiar for a children's film adaptation. "Without the Disney seal of approval, audiences are a bit wary of these fairy tale adaptations," said Jeff Bock, a box office analyst with Exhibitor Relations. He added, "It veered off the Peter Pan path quite extensively and it was just too far left of center for a generation that grew up with ''Hook'' and sees that as the definitive account."{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/pan-box-office-bomb-death-of-origin-movies-1201615656/|title=Does 'Pan's' Box Office Bomb Spell the End for Origin Stories?|author=Brent Lang|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=([[Penske Media Corporation]])|date=October 12, 2015|accessdate=October 14, 2015}} Warner Bros. declined to discuss ''Pan''{{'}}s box office results. ''Pan'' also struggled internationally, grossing $20.4 million on its opening weekend from 54 markets from over 11,000 screens. 3D comprised 85% of the opening gross.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/10/the-martian-pan-hotel-transylvania-2-inside-out-the-walk-international-box-office-results-1201575166/|title='The Martian' Crosses $118.5M Offshore; 'Pan' Serves Up Est. $20.4M – Intl B.O. Final|author=Nancy Tartaglione|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=([[Penske Media Corporation]])|date=October 12, 2015|accessdate=October 13, 2015}} The film was released in Australia on September 24, 2015, to take advantage of the prime September school holidays, where it grossed $1.5 million in its opening weekend. Elsewhere, it opened in the U.K. with $4.1 million, and No. 1 in Mexico ($2.9 million), Brazil ($1.8 million), Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand and No. 2 in Russia and the CIS with $2 million (behind ''The Martian''), Spain with $1.7 million (behind ''[[Regression (film)|Regression]]''), Hong Kong, Singapore and the Philippines.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/10/crimson-peak-ant-man-martian-hotel-transylvania-scorch-trials-pan-international-box-office-results-1201586990/|title='Ant-Man' Supersizes With $43.2M China Bow; 'Crimson Peak' Reaps $13.4M – International Box Office|author=Nancy Tartaglione|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=October 18, 2015|accessdate=October 19, 2015}} ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' estimated that the film cost $275 million to produce and market worldwide—while ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported at least $250 million—and noted that the financial losses by Warner Bros. could finish anywhere between $130 to $150 million. The site suggested that if the film overperformed in China—the world's second largest movie market—the losses could have been lower. Opening in China on October 22, 2015, it failed to meet expectations. Based on its production cost and factoring in the percentage of ticket sales kept by theater owners, analysts estimated that ''Pan'' needed to take in at least $400–500 million worldwide to [[break even]].{{cite web|url=http://mobile.nytimes.com/2015/10/12/movies/pan-bombs-at-the-box-office.html |title='Pan' Bombs at the Box Office|author=Brooks Barnes|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=October 11, 2015|accessdate=October 14, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/why-china-is-panning-pan-835052|title=Why China Is Panning 'Pan'|author=Patrick Brzeski|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=([[Prometheus Global Media]])|date=October 28, 2015|accessdate=October 29, 2015}} The financial loss incurred by ''Pan'' puts it alongside ''[[Tomorrowland (film)|Tomorrowland]]'' and ''[[Jupiter Ascending]]'' as one of the biggest box office failures of 2015. ===Critical response=== On review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 27%, based on 184 reviews, and an average rating of 4.6/10. The website's critical consensus reads, "''Pan'' finds a few bursts of magic in its prequel treatment of classic characters, though not enough to offset the rushed plot and shrill, CGI-fueled action."{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/pan_2015/|title=Pan (2015) |publisher=[[Fandango Media]] |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=April 23, 2018}} On [[Metacritic]], the film a score of 36 out of 100 based on reviews from 35 critics, indicating "generally unfavorable reviews".{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/pan|title=Pan Reviews |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |work=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=October 11, 2015}} A.O. Scott of ''[[The New York Times]]'' called the action scenes "murky and chaotic" and stated, "The dominant emotion in ''Pan'' is the desperation of the filmmakers, who frantically try to pander to a young audience they don’t seem to respect, understand or trust."{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/09/movies/review-pan-proposes-peter-and-captain-hooks-origin-stories.html?partner=rss&emc=rss|title=Review: ‘Pan’ Proposes Peter and Captain Hook’s Origin Stories|last=Scott|first=A.O.|date=October 8, 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=August 7, 2018}} The main characters lacked chemistry and depth according to Todd McCarthy of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', who added that with the exception of Levi Miller's Pan, "the characters don't reasonably comport with one's pre-existing images of them". He also called a good portion of the film "a seriously extended chase that possesses hefty CGI-propelled dynamics but absolutely no suspense and a very limited sense of fun".{{cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/pan-film-review-824864|title='Pan': Film Review|last=McCarthy|first=Todd|date=September 19, 2015|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=August 7, 2018}} Andrew Barker of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' praised the film's technical achievements and action sequences but found it depressing overall: "''Pan'' swaps puckish mischief and innocence for doses of [[Steampunk]] design, anachronistic music, a stock “chosen one” narrative and themes of child labor, warfare and unsustainable mineral mining exchanges".{{cite news |url=https://variety.com/2015/film/reviews/film-review-pan-1201596436/|title=Film Review: 'Pan' |author=Andrew Barker|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=September 19, 2015|accessdate=September 20, 2015}} In a more positive review, Bill Zwecker of ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' gave the film 3 out of 4 stars, calling Levi Miller "a truly wonderful cinematic discovery" and adding that the film is "chock-full with thrilling action sequences, vivid costumes and well-executed special effects".{{cite news|url=http://www.pressreader.com/usa/chicago-sun-times/20151009/283270276606347/TextView|title=From Boy to 'Pan': Jaunty Jackman, talented newcomer star in prequel pulsating with action|last=Zwecker|first=Bill|date=October 9, 2015|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|accessdate=August 7, 2018}} Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "B+" on an A+ to F scale, while [[PostTrak]] reported filmgoers gave it a 78% overall positive score. ===Accolades=== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! [[File:Astaire Puttin on the Ritz.jpg|right|thumb|245px|
Fred Astaire and a chorus of Fred Astaires performing "Puttin' On the Ritz" in ''[[Blue Skies (1946 film)|Blue Skies]]'' (1946).]] [[File:Idiot's Delight lobby card.jpg|thumb|245px|
[[Clark Gable]]'s deliberately corny performance of the song in ''[[Idiot's Delight (film)|Idiot's Delight]]'' (1939), his only musical performance.]] "'''Puttin' On the Ritz'''" is a song written by [[Irving Berlin]]. He wrote it in May 1927 and first published it on December 2, 1929.{{sfn|Kimball|Emmet|2001|p=262}} It was registered as an unpublished song August 24, 1927 and again on July 27, 1928.{{sfn|Kimball|Emmet|2001|p=262}} It was introduced by [[Harry Richman]] and chorus in the musical film ''[[Puttin' On the Ritz (film)|Puttin' On the Ritz]]'' (1930). According to ''The Complete Lyrics of Irving Berlin'', this was the first song in film to be sung by an interracial ensemble.{{sfn|Kimball|Emmet|2001|p=262}} The title derives from the [[slang]] expression "to put on the Ritz", meaning to dress very fashionably. The expression was inspired by the opulent [[The Ritz Hotel, London|Ritz Hotel]]. Hit [[gramophone record|phonograph records]] of the tune in its original period of popularity of 1929–1930 were recorded by [[Harry Richman]] and by [[Fred Astaire]], with whom the song is particularly associated. Every other record label had their own version of this popular song (Columbia, Brunswick, Victor, and all of the dime store labels). Richman's Brunswick version of the song became the number-one selling record in America.{{sfn|Kimball|Emmet|2001|p=262}} The song received renewed popularity and became known to a new generation of fans in 1983 when [[Taco (musician)|Taco]], a Dutch musician, recorded and released a new version of the song. Taco's version was accompanied by a music video, which aired on [[MTV]] and other music video networks and programs. ==Musical structure== The song is in [[Thirty-two-bar form|AABA form]], with a verse.{{sfn|Mueller|1986|p=267}} According to [[John Mueller]], the central device in the A section is the "use of delayed rhythmic resolution: a staggering, off-balance passage, emphasized by the unorthodox stresses in the lyric, suddenly resolves satisfyingly on a held note, followed by the forceful assertion of the title phrase." The marchlike B section, which is only barely [[Syncopation|syncopated]], acts as a contrast to the previous rhythmic complexities.{{sfn|Mueller|1986|p=267}} According to [[Alec Wilder]], in his study of American popular song, for him, the rhythmic pattern in "Puttin' On the Ritz" is "the most complex and provocative I have ever come upon."{{sfn|Mueller|1986|p=267}} ==Lyrics and race== The original version of Berlin's song included references to the then-popular fad of flashily-dressed but poor [[Black people|black]] [[Harlem]]ites parading up and down [[Lenox Avenue]], "Spending ev'ry dime / For a wonderful time". In the United Kingdom, the song was popularized through the BBC's radio broadcasts of [[Joe Kaye's Band]] performing it at [[The Ritz Hotel, London]] restaurant in the 1930s.{{sfn|Montgomery-Massingberd|Watkin|Collie|p=97}} The song was featured with the original lyrics in the 1939 film ''[[Idiot's Delight (film)|Idiot's Delight]]'', where it was performed by [[Clark Gable]] and chorus, and this routine was selected for inclusion in ''[[That's Entertainment!|That's Entertainment]]'' (1974). Columbia released a [[Gramophone record#78 rpm disc developments|78 recording]] of [[Fred Astaire]] singing the original lyrics in May 1930{{cite web|title= Puttin' On the Ritz / Crazy Feet |publisher= [[Rate Your Music]] |url= http://rateyourmusic.com/release/single/fred_astaire/puttin_on_the_ritz___crazy_feet/ |accessdate= May 8, 2016}} (B-side – "Crazy Feet", both recorded on March 26, 1930). For the film ''[[Blue Skies (1946 film)|Blue Skies]]'' (1946), where it was performed by Fred Astaire, Berlin revised the lyrics to apply to affluent whites strutting "up and down [[Park Avenue (Manhattan)|Park Avenue]]".{{sfn|Kimball|Emmet|2001|p=262}}{{efn-ua|"In the original version it told of the ritzy airs of Harlemites parading up and down Lenox Avenue. For the 1946 film, the strutters became well-to-do whites on Park Avenue. The patronizing, yet admiring satire of the song is shifted, then, and mellowed in the process. The change may have had to do with changing attitudes towards race and with Hollywood's dawning wariness about offending blacks."{{sfn|Mueller|1986|p=267}}}} This second version was published after being registered for copyright on August 28, 1946.{{sfn|Kimball|Emmet|2001|p=262}} ==Taco version== {{Infobox song | name = Puttin' On the Ritz | cover = Taco Puttin on the Ritz.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Taco (musician)|Taco]] | album = After Eight | B-side = Livin' in My Dream World | released = 1982 | format = [[7"]], [[12-inch single|12"]] | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Synth-pop]]{{cite web|first= Jason |last= Ankeny |title= Taco – Artist Biography |publisher= [[AllMusic]]. [[All Media Network]] |url= http://www.allmusic.com/artist/taco-mn0000019028/biography |accessdate= May 8, 2016}} | length = 4:41 (Album version)
3:22 (7" version)
6:08 (Extended 12" version) | label = [[RCA Records|RCA]] | writer = Irving Berlin | producer = David Parker | prev_title = Cheek to Cheek | prev_year = 1982 | next_title = [[Singin' in the Rain (song)|Singin' in the Rain]] | next_year = 1992 | misc = {{External music video|{{YouTube|pTtIF8kkDIY|"Puttin' On the Ritz" (''TopPop'', 1983)}}}} }} In 1982, singer [[Taco (musician)|Taco]] released a [[synth-pop]] [[cover version]] of "Puttin' On the Ritz" as a single from his album ''After Eight'', released on [[Polydor Records|Polydor]] of Germany. The single was accompanied by a music video, the original version of which contains characters in [[blackface]] and has since been banned from many networks. An alternative version eliminates many shots of the blackface characters, though some remain. The single was a global hit, reaching No. 1 in ''[[Cashbox (magazine)|Cashbox]]'' as well as No. 4 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart, making Irving Berlin, then 95, the oldest ever living songwriter to have one of his compositions enter the top ten.{{cite web|title= Irving Berlin |publisher= Russian Heritage Museum |url= http://russianheritagemuseum.com/en/RHM_Irving_Berlin/ |accessdate= May 10, 2016}} It was certified [[Music recording sales certification|Gold]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]] for selling over one million copies.{{cite web|title= RIAA – Gold & Platinum Searchable Database – Puttin' On the Ritz |url= https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/?tab_active=default-award&ar=Taco&ti=Puttin%27+On+the+Ritz#search_section |publisher= [[Recording Industry Association of America]] |accessdate= May 8, 2016}} It was Taco's only hit in the United States. This version of the song was ranked No. 53 in [[VH1]]'s ''[[The Greatest (TV series)|100 Greatest One Hit Wonders of the 80s]]'' special. The song topped the charts in Sweden and New Zealand, and it entered the Top 5 in numerous countries including Australia, Norway, Austria and Canada. The Taco cover of the song was used in ''[[Baby Geniuses]]'' (1999) and ''[[The Call (2013 film)|The Call]]'' (2013). [[Alvin and the Chipmunks]] covered Taco's version of the song for "Don't Be a Vidiot", a 1984 episode of ''[[Alvin and the Chipmunks (1983 TV series)|Alvin and the Chipmunks]]''. ===Chart history=== {{col-float|width=30em}} ====Weekly singles charts==== {|class="wikitable sortable" !Chart (1982–1983) !Peak

revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Use British English|date=July 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox company | name = Quantic Dream SA | logo = Quantic Dream.svg | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | industry = [[Video game industry]] | founded = {{Start date and age|df=yes|1997|06|03}} | founder = [[David Cage]] | hq_location_city = [[Paris]] | hq_location_country = France | key_people = {{Unbulleted list|David Cage {{small|([[President (corporate title)|president]])}}|Philippe Limantour {{small|([[managing director]])}}|[[Guillaume de Fondaumière]] {{small|([[chief operating officer]])}}}} | num_employees = {{Decrease}} 180 | num_employees_year = 2018 | website = {{URL|http://quanticdream.com/en/|quanticdream.com}} }}
'''Quantic Dream SA''' is a French [[video game developer]] based in Paris. Founded in June 1997, Quantic Dream has developed five video games: ''[[The Nomad Soul]]'' (1999), ''[[Fahrenheit (2005 video game)|Fahrenheit]]'' (2005), ''[[Heavy Rain]]'' (2010), ''[[Beyond: Two Souls]]'' (2013), and ''[[Detroit: Become Human]]'' (2018). Quantic Dream is known for promoting [[interactive storytelling]], with founder [[David Cage]] as the primary creative force.
== History == [[David Cage]], after fifteen years as a composer, started writing the concept and story of ''[[The Nomad Soul]]'' in 1994. He ended up with a 200-page document and sent it to contacts he had acquired during his time making music, who noted that its execution would not be technically feasible. To prove them wrong, Cage hired a team of friends and made an office out of a [[Recording studio|sound booth]], with a financial deadline of six months to come up with a [[game engine]] and [[prototype]]. In the final week, Cage travelled to [[London]] and met with publisher [[Eidos Interactive]].{{efn|The year this occurred has both been reported as 1997 and 1998.<ref name="MCV-Sep2011" /><ref name="Edge-Sep2013" />}} With the project funded and a publisher secured, ''The Nomad Soul'' was in full development; musician [[David Bowie]] played two characters and created ten original songs. On 3 June 1997, Cage founded the company as Quantic Dream [[S.A. (corporation)|SA]]; the name draws influence from the term "[[quantum physics]]".<ref name="MCV-Sep2011" /><ref name="Wilms-May2018" /><ref name="Batchelor-Oct2016" /> The game released in November 1999, selling more than 600,000 copies.<ref name="Edge-Sep2013" /><ref name="Gibson-Mar2005" />
[[File:David Cage 20080927 Festival du jeu video 04.jpg|thumb|David Cage in 2008]] In 2004, Quantic Dream provided [[motion capture]] for the film ''[[Immortal (2004 film)|Immortal]]''.<ref name="Murphy-Oct2013" /> They followed ''The Nomad Soul'' with ''[[Fahrenheit (2005 video game)|Fahrenheit]]'', published by [[Atari, Inc. (Atari, SA subsidiary)|Atari, Inc.]] in September 2005, introducing elements that would endure in their later games—[[ethical]] ambiguity, [[Romance (love)|romance]], the inability to perish, and [[interactive storytelling]]. It received multiple awards and sold over one million copies.<ref name="MCV-Sep2011" /><ref name="Quantic Dream" /> The same year, Quantic Dream revealed ''The Casting'', a [[technology demonstration]] of what could be accomplished on [[PlayStation 3]].<ref name="Wilms-May2018" /><ref name="Robinson-Mar2012" /> This preceded the partnership with [[Sony Computer Entertainment]] to bring ''[[Heavy Rain]]'' into existence, marking "something more personal" for Cage.<ref name="MCV-Sep2011" /> ''Heavy Rain'' launched in 2010 to critical acclaim,<ref name="MCPS3-A" /> winning three awards at the [[7th British Academy Games Awards]] and selling a total of 5.3 million copies.<ref name="Dutton-Mar2011" /><ref name="Audureau-Jan2018" /> By late 2011, another deal had been established with Sony.<ref name="MCV-Sep2011" /> The following year, Quantic Dream showed another PlayStation 3 tech demo, ''Kara'', taking advantage of new investments in motion capture facilities.<ref name="Robinson-Mar2012" /> The second title with Sony was 2013's ''[[Beyond: Two Souls]]'', starring actress [[Ellen Page]] and actor [[Willem Dafoe]],<ref name="Batchelor-Oct2016" /><ref name="Brightman-Jul2012" /> which received mixed reviews from critics and managed to sell 2.8 million copies.<ref name="MCPS3-B" /><ref name="Caballero-Jul2018" /> It was the second video game to be shown at the [[Tribeca Film Festival]] in 2013,<ref name="Gaston-Mar2013" /> the same year that ''The Dark Sorcerer'', a tech demo running on [[PlayStation 4]], was unveiled at [[E3]].<ref name="Funk-Jun2013" />
In 2014, Quantic Dream doubled their investment in Vicon, whose motion capture technology was previously used in ''Heavy Rain'' and ''Beyond: Two Souls''.<ref name="Vicon-Apr2014" /> The company's fifth video game and third published by Sony, ''[[Detroit: Become Human]]'', was announced the year after. Based on the ''Kara'' tech demo,<ref name="Goldfarb-Oct2015" /> it spent four years in development before releasing in May 2018.<ref name="deFondaumiere-Apr2018" /><ref name="Cage-Mar2018" /> Quantic Dream's most successful launch to date,<ref name="Grubb-Jun2018" /> it has sold 1.5 million copies.<ref name="Harradence-Aug2018" /> Around that time, Quantic Dream employed 180 staff members,<ref name="Purchese-Jan2018" /> five fewer than were reported in 2016.<ref name="InsidePlayStation-Aug2016" />
== Controversy == In January 2018, three French news outlets—''[[Le Monde]]'',<ref name="Audureau-Jan2018" /> ''[[Mediapart]]'',<ref name="GoanecIsrael-Jan2018" /> and ''[[Canard PC]]''<ref name="Kalash-Jan2018" />—published the results of a joint investigation into the company's business practices, alleging a harmful studio culture, overwork, and sexist or racist behaviour by employees. The reports named Cage and chief operating officer [[Guillaume de Fondaumière]] as perpetrators of inappropriate behaviour and overworking the staff. Controversial images exchanged by email and posted around the office included photos of studio collaborators and employees digitally edited to appear as Nazis and porn stars.<ref name="Phillips-Jul2018" /> Cage said the allegations were "ridiculous, absurd and grotesque"; de Fondaumière stated, "I will be extremely clear: it's absolutely false".<ref name="Purchese-Jan2018" /> As a result, Quantic Dream levied a [[lawsuit]] against ''Le Monde'' and ''Mediapart'', while ''Canard PC'' received two "threatening letters".<ref name="Schreier-Apr2018" /> That July, Quantic Dream lost one court case against an employee who left due to the scandal.<ref name="Phillips-Jul2018" />
== Philosophy == Quantic Dream's video games are written and directed by Cage and [[brand]]ed accordingly, with the purpose of making new [[intellectual properties]].<ref name="MCV-Sep2011" /><ref name="Gibson-Mar2013" /> Cage has declared that his mission is to evoke [[emotion]] through interactive storytelling, highlighting [[empathy]], [[sadness]], and [[Guilt (emotion)|guilt]] in opposition to [[frustration]], [[competition]], and [[anger]]. As such, he described purchasing ''Heavy Rain'' as a "political act" that others like it could be made.<ref name="Welsh-Feb2010" /><ref name="Ingham-Mar2011" /><ref name="Edge-Jul2012" /> The developer strives to appeal to gamers and non-gamers alike,<ref name="Gallagher-Mar2011" /> considering video games to be the same as any artform.<ref name="Batchelor-Oct2016" /> It is customary at Quantic Dream to develop an engine for each new game, hardware, or platform; Cage believes that, while an engine's methodology can be [[Porting|ported]], its code cannot.<ref name="MCV-Sep2011" /><ref name="Edge-Jul2012" /> Tech demos have likewise become tradition.<ref name="Robinson-Mar2012" /><ref name="Funk-Jun2013" /><ref name="Hanson-Sep2013" /> In France, Quantic Dream is afforded a 20% [[tax break]] on production costs, without which Cage would move the company to [[Canada]] to keep up with the competition.<ref name="MCV-Sep2011" />
== Games developed == {| class="wikitable unsortable" ! Year ! Title ! Platform(s) ! Publisher(s) |- | 1999 | ''[[The Nomad Soul]]''{{efn|''The Nomad Soul'' was retitled ''Omikron: The Nomad Soul'' in North America, which Cage saw as the publisher's lack of confidence in its marketability and said contributed to its poor sales.<ref name="MCV-Sep2011" />}} | [[Dreamcast]], [[Microsoft Windows]]<ref name="Sarkar-Jan2016" /> | [[Eidos Interactive]] |- | 2005 | ''[[Fahrenheit (2005 video game)|Fahrenheit]]''{{efn|''Fahrenheit'' was retitled ''Indigo Prophecy'' for the North American release; Cage accused the publisher of not seeing its market potential.<ref name="MCV-Sep2011" />}} | [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[iOS]], [[Linux]], [[macOS]], Microsoft Windows, [[PlayStation 2]], [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]]<ref name="Matulef-Jun2016" /> | [[Atari, Inc. (Atari, SA subsidiary)|Atari, Inc.]] |- | 2010 | ''[[Heavy Rain]]'' | rowspan="2" | [[PlayStation 3]], PlayStation 4<ref name="O'Brien-Jun2015" /> | rowspan="2" | [[Sony Computer Entertainment]] |- | 2013 | ''[[Beyond: Two Souls]]'' |- | 2018 | ''[[Detroit: Become Human]]'' | PlayStation 4<ref name="Cage-Mar2018" /> | Sony Interactive Entertainment |}

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Shanghai Express | image = Shanghai Express film poster.jpg | caption = [[Film poster|Theatrical lobby card]] | director = [[Josef von Sternberg]] | producer = [[Adolph Zukor]] | based on = {{Based on|"Sky Over China" aka "China Pass"
unpublished novel|[[Harry Hervey]]}} | writer = [[Jules Furthman]]
[[Harry Hervey]] (story) | starring = [[Marlene Dietrich]]
[[Clive Brook]]
[[Anna May Wong]] | music = W. Franke Harling
Rudolph G. Kopp | cinematography = [[Lee Garmes]]
[[James Wong Howe]] | editing = [[Frank Sullivan (film editing)|Frank Sullivan]] | distributor = [[Paramount Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1932|02|12}} | runtime = 80 minutes | country = [[United States]] | language = [[English language|English]] (primarily), [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]], [[Mandarin Chinese|Mandarin]] | budget = | gross =$3.7 million }} '''''Shanghai Express''''' is a 1932 American [[Pre-Code Hollywood|pre-Code]] film directed by [[Josef von Sternberg]] and starring [[Marlene Dietrich]], [[Clive Brook]], [[Anna May Wong]], and [[Warner Oland]]. It was written by [[Jules Furthman]], based on a 1931 story by [[Harry Hervey]]. ''Shanghai Express'' was the fourth of seven films von Sternberg and Dietrich made together. ''Shanghai Express'' was released during the midst of the [[Great Depression]]. The film was a huge hit with the public, grossing $3.7 million in its initial screenings in the United States alone, becoming the biggest financial success of the Dietrich-von Sternberg collaborations, and was the highest-grossing movie of 1932, surpassing the all-star ''[[Grand Hotel (1932 film)|Grand Hotel]]''. ''Shanghai Express'' was remade as ''[[Night Plane from Chungking]]'' (1942) and ''[[Peking Express (film)|Peking Express]]'' (1951). {{TOC limit|limit=2}} ==Plot== [[File:Shanghai Express (film) 1932 Josef von Sternberg, dir - (L-R) Marlene Dietrich, Clive Brook.jpg|left|thumb|(L-R) Marlene Dietrich (Madeleine/Shanghai Lily) and Clive Brook (Donald "Doc" Harvey)]] In 1931, China is embroiled in a [[Chinese Civil War|civil war]]. Friends of British Captain Donald "Doc" Harvey ([[Clive Brook]]) envy him because the fabulously notorious Shanghai Lily ([[Marlene Dietrich]]) is a fellow passenger on the express train from [[Beijing|Peking]] to [[Shanghai]]. Because the name means nothing to him, they inform him that she is a "coaster" or "woman who lives by her wits along the China coast" – in other words, a [[courtesan]]. On the journey, Harvey encounters Lily, who turns out to be his former lover, Madeline. Five years earlier, she had played a trick on Harvey to gauge his love for her, but it backfired and he left her. She frankly informs him that, in the interim, "It took more than one man to change my name to Shanghai Lily." When Lily makes it clear that she still cares deeply for him, it becomes apparent that his feelings also have not changed when she inadvertently sees the watch she gave him with her photograph still in it. Among the other passengers are fellow coaster Hui Fei ([[Anna May Wong]]), Lily's companion; Christian missionary Mr. Carmichael ([[Lawrence Grant]]), who at first condemns the two "fallen women"; inveterate gambler Sam Salt ([[Eugene Pallette]]); [[opium]] dealer Eric Baum ([[Gustav von Seyffertitz]]); [[boarding house]] keeper Mrs. Haggerty ([[Louise Closser Hale]]); French officer Major Lenard ([[Emile Chautard]]) and a mysterious [[Eurasian (mixed ancestry)|Eurasian]], Henry Chang ([[Warner Oland]]). Chinese government soldiers board and search the train and apprehend a high-ranking rebel agent. Chang then makes his way to a telegraph office and sends a coded message. Later, the train is stopped and taken over by the rebel army and its powerful warlord, who turns out to be Chang. Chang begins to question the passengers, looking for someone important enough to exchange for his valued aide. He finds what he wants in Harvey, who is on his way to perform brain surgery on the Governor-General of Shanghai. Chang offers to take Shanghai Lily to his palace, but she claims she has reformed. When Chang refuses to accept her answer, Harvey breaks in and knocks him down. Because Chang needs Harvey alive, he swallows (but does not forget) the insult. Chang then has Hui Fei brought to him in his quarters, where he forces himself on her. The government releases Chang's man, but Chang decides to blind Harvey for his insolence. Out of love, Lily offers herself in return for Harvey's safe release. Harvey remains unaware of the danger that he is in and of Lily's reason for going with Chang. Chang is stabbed to death by Hui Fei who tells Harvey what has transpired. Finding Lily, the trio boards the train and departs before the body is discovered. The missionary Carmichael, trusting his instincts, gets Lily to reveal the truth about saving Harvey. She insists that he not enlighten Harvey because love must go hand in hand with faith. When the train finally reaches Shanghai safely, Lily offers Harvey her love unconditionally but demands the same in return. Harvey finally breaks down and embraces her. ==Cast== * [[Clive Brook]] as Captain Donald "Doc" Harvey * [[Marlene Dietrich]] as Shanghai Lily / Madeline * [[Anna May Wong]] as Hui Fei * [[Warner Oland]] as Henry Chang * [[Lawrence Grant]] as Reverend Carmichael * [[Eugene Pallette]] as Sam Salt * [[Gustav von Seyffertitz]] as Eric Baum * [[Louise Closser Hale]] as Mrs. Haggerty * [[Emile Chautard]] as Major Lenard ==Production== [[File:Anna May Wong Shanghai Express.jpg|thumb|Anna May Wong in one of her rare appearances in a major role during the 1930s, appearing with Marlene Dietrich in ''Shanghai Express''. {{refn|Although starring in features, in the 1930s, Wong continued to be assigned supporting roles.Liu 2000, p. 24.|group=Note}}]] Although set in China, there were few Chinese actors in the production.Leong 2005, pp. 181–182. In production from August to November 1931, ''Shanghai Express'' was released in 1932.{{sfnb|Dixon|2012}} {{page needed|date=July 2015}} Based on Henry Hervey's story ("Sky Over China," also known as "China Pass"), ''Shanghai Express'' was, in turn, loosely based on the May 6, 1923, incident in which a Shandong warlord captured the Shanghai to Beijing express train, where 25 westerners and 300 Chinese were taken hostage. All of the hostages captured in the [[Lincheng Outrage]] were successfully ransomed,French 2006 {{page needed|date=July 2015}}Nozinski 1990 {{page needed|date=July 2015}} including [[Lucy Aldrich]]. [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount studio]] heads were concerned that the [[Motion Picture Production Code|Hays Office]] kept a close watch on the film due to the portrayal of the Reverend Carmichael and the depiction of the Chinese revolution.[http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/89803/Shanghai-Express/notes.html "Notes: 'Shanghai Express'."] ''Turner Classic Movies''. Retrieved: July 2, 2015. The story also echoes elements of [[Guy de Maupassant]]'s short story "[[Boule de Suif]]" in the setting of travellers stopped in a country at war and a woman called upon to sleep with the commander in charge. However the denouement is altered, and while the travellers are released, the woman murders the commander and her fellow travelling companions change their attitude towards her. ==Reception== [[File:Marlene Dietrich in Shanghai Express (1932) by Don English.png|thumb|left|Marlene Dietrich in ''Shanghai Express'']] ''Shanghai Express'' was dubbed "''[[Grand Hotel (1932 film)|Grand Hotel]]'' on wheels". Critically reviewed, the film was praised by Mordaunt Hall of ''[[The New York Times]]'' as a star vehicle for [[Marlene Dietrich]]. "Miss Dietrich gives an impressive performance. She is langourous but fearless as Lily." Other characters are also singled out, "Clive Brooks's performance is also noteworthy ..." "... Warner Oland is excellent as Mr. Chang and [[Anna May Wong]] makes the most of the rôle of the brave Chinese girl. Eugene Pallette serves splendidly as Sam Salt."Hall, Mordaunt. [https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9C04E6DD1E3EE333A2575BC1A9649C946394D6CF "'Shanghai Express' (1932): Marlene Dietrich in a brilliantly directed melodrama set aboard a train running from Peiping to Shanghai."] ''The New York Times'', February 18, 1932. [[Jonathan Spence]], writing about the film's usefulness as a piece of history says that the real events of 1923 Lincheng Incident were far more dramatic but says that nonetheless it is "a wonderful film, with great performances by Dietrich – 'it took more than one man to change my name to Shanghai Lily' – and Anna May Wong." {{sfnb|Spence|1996| p =210}} The critic for ''[[Senses of Cinema]]'' called ''Shanghai Express'', (a) "riotous exercise in excess in every area; the visuals are overpowering and sumptuous; the costumes ornate and extravagant; the sets a riot of fabrics, light and space; and all of it captured in the most delectable black-and-white cinematography that one can find anywhere." He discusses the film's interest in the questions of race and colonialism and notes the "peculiar bifurcation" of the film's view of race; most of the respectable "white" characters in the film are seen as both flawed and racist. Only Dietrich, Wong, and to some extent "Doc" Harvey, have any "real moral agency." He calls the film "surprisingly feminist," with Dietrich being a "strong, dominating presence" and Wong's character her equal.{{sfnb|Dixon|2012}} {{page needed|date=July 2015}} ''Shanghai Express'' is memorable for its stylistic black-and-white [[chiaroscuro]] cinematography. Even though [[Lee Garmes]] was awarded the [[Academy Award for Best Cinematography]], according to Dietrich, it was von Sternberg who was responsible for most of it.Landazuri, Margarita. [http://www.tcm.com/this-month/article/18558%7C0/Shanghai-Express.html "Shanghai Express."] ''Turner Classic Movies''. Retrieved: July 2, 2015. ==Awards and honors== {| class="wikitable" style="margin:auto; width:100%;" |- ! Award !! Category !! Nominee !! Outcome |- |rowspan="3"|[[5th Academy Awards]]
([[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]]){{cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1933 |title=The 5th Academy Awards (1932) Nominees and Winners |accessdate=February 6, 2014|work=oscars.org}}||[[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]]||''Shanghai Express''
Winner was ''[[Grand Hotel (1932 film)|Grand Hotel]]''||{{nom}} |- |[[Academy Award for Best Director|Best Director]]||[[Josef von Sternberg]]
Winner was [[Frank Borzage]] – ''[[Bad Girl (1931 film)|Bad Girl]]''||{{nom}} |- |[[Academy Award for Best Cinematography|Best Cinematography]]||[[Lee Garmes]]||{{win}} |- |} The film is recognized by [[American Film Institute]] in these lists: * 2005: [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Movie Quotes]]: ** Shanghai Lily: "It took more than one man to change my name to Shanghai Lily." – Nominated{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/quotes400.pdf |title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Movie Quotes Nominees |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2016-07-30}} ==References== ===Notes=== {{Reflist|group=Note}} ===Citations=== {{Reflist|30em}} ===Bibliography=== {{Refbegin}} * {{cite journal |last =Dixon |first =Wheeler Winston|authorlink = |title =Shanghai Express |journal =Senses of Cinema, 2012 |volume = |issue = 62 |pages = |publisher = |location = |date =|language = |url = http://sensesofcinema.com/2012/cteq/shanghai-express/ |jstor = |issn = |doi = |accessdate = |ref= harv}} * French, Paul. ''Carl Crow, a Tough Old China Hand: The Life, Times, and Adventures of an American in Shanghai''. Hong Kong: Hong Kong University Press, 2006. {{ISBN|962-209-802-9}}. * Leong, Karen J. ''The China Mystique: Pearl S. Buck, Anna May Wong, Mayling Soong, and the Transformation of American Orientalism''. Berkeley, California: University of California Press, 2005. {{ISBN|0-520-24422-2}}. * Liu, Cynthia W. "When Dragon Ladies Die, Do They Come Back as Butterflies? Re-imagining Anna May Wong." ''Countervisions: Asian American Film Criticism''. Hamamoto, Darrel and Sandra Liu, (editors). Philadelphia: Temple University Press, 2000, pp. 23–39. {{ISBN|1-56639-776-6}}. * Nozinski, Michael J. ''Outrage at Lincheng: China Enters the Twentieth Century''. Centennial, Colorado: Glenbridge Publishing Ltd., 1990. {{ISBN|978-0-9444-3507-6}}. * {{citation | first= Jonathan | last =Spence | chapter = Shanghai Express | pages =208–211| title = Past Imperfect: History According to the Movies | series = | volume = | editor-first = Mark C.| editor-last =Carnes | location = New York| publisher =Holt, 1996 | year =| isbn = |url= |ref = harv}} {{Refend}} == External links == * {{tcmdb title|89803|Shanghai Express}} * {{IMDb title|0023458|Shanghai Express}} * {{Amg movie|44084|Shanghai Express}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|id=1043598-shanghai_express|title=Shanghai Express}} * [http://www.virtual-history.com/movie/film/503/shanghai-express ''Shanghai Express''] at Virtual History {{Josef von Sternberg}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Shanghai Express (Film)}} [[Category:1932 films]] [[Category:1930s drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American romantic drama films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Josef von Sternberg]] [[Category:Films made before the MPAA Production Code]] [[Category:Films set in 1931]] [[Category:Films set in China]] [[Category:Films set in Shanghai]] [[Category:Films whose cinematographer won the Best Cinematography Academy Award]] [[Category:Paramount Pictures films]] [[Category:Rail transport films]] [[Category:Screenplays by Jules Furthman]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} '''Shutdown Day''' was an [[Internet]] campaign active between 2007 and 2009 which promoted the idea of a [[holiday]] when people would go without a [[computer]] for the entire day. The benefits attributed to not using a computer for 24 hours range from electricity savings to getting back in touch with friends and [[nature]].
== Establishment ==
===Founders=== Denis Bystrov and Nikolay Kudrevatykh were the co-founders of Shutdown Day; Bystrov originally conceived the idea of Shutdown Day, and the co-founders developed the concept in 2007, while living in [[Canada]].<ref name="sdd-about">{{cite web|url=http://www.shutdownday.org/about.php|title=Can you survive for 24 hours without your computer ?|date=2008|publisher=Shutdown Day|accessdate=2009-02-27|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090122192243/http://shutdownday.org/about.php|archivedate=2009-01-22|df=}}</ref> Michael Taylor, an original partner in the idea of shutting down one's [[computer]] down for a day, said:
{{quote|I certainly could not and would not want to live without my computer. However, I am often drawn into spending hours chatting on MSN, simply because my friends are online instead of socialising face to face. I am often too busy to cook a proper dinner, because I want to see the latest news on digg.com or the latest YouTube video. I know parents who are so addicted to the computer that they spend little time with their children, and I also know children who do not spend time with their parents because they are always using the computer. We are not preaching to anyone to turn off their computers. We are just suggesting that people might like to take part in this experiment, and see what happens.}}
Many thanks to our friend Andrei Dryzgalovich who designed, developed and technically supported our project.
== Purpose and goals == Shutdown Day is a global Internet experiment whose purpose is to get people to think about how their lives have changed with the increasing use of the home computer, and whether or not any good things are being lost because of this.<ref name="sdd-about" /> The concept of the ''Shutdown Day'' project is to simply shutdown one's computer for one whole day each year, and become involved in other activities: outdoors, nature, sports, fun stuff with friends and family, just to remind yourself that there is a real world beyond the computer screen.
== History ==
Shutdown Day started in early 2007, when Denis Bystrov realized that he spent too much time with his computer and wanted to spend more time with his family. Bystrov teamed up with his friends Nikolay Kudrevatykh, Michael Taylor (former trade floor occupant in stock markets in London, [[England]]) and David Bridle (part-time film maker from Cardiff, Wales), to present a challenge on the Internet, through the website shutdownday.org, challenging people to avoid their computers for 24 hours. The idea was simple:
{{quote|Do you think you can stay away from your computers for at least 24 hours a day, and if yes, can you pledge to do so?}}
What began as an innocent question, gathered an Internet chain reaction following, which drew millions of viewers from across the world. Here is a summary of the results from the Shutdown Day 2007 campaign:
* The Shutdown Day website received more than 1.6 million visitors in the first month of the campaign. * More than 65,000 people participated in the campaign by actually shutting down their computers for 24 hours on the 24th of March, 2007. * The Shutdown Day promotional clip was broadcast on YouTube and received more than 1.1 million hits.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q8OMijrTVBU|title=Shutdown Day 2007 Official Video on Youtube)}}</ref> * 450,000 visitors signed up for country locater on Shutdown Day website. * The idea of Shutdown Day featured on more than 200,000 online forums discussions, television interviews, and popular media. Services that covered Shutdown Day included Globe and Mail, CNN, Fox News,<ref name="Fox News 07">{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,253373,00.html|title=Get Ready for Shutdown Day|last=Hughes|first=Spencer|date=20 February 2007|work=The News According to Hughes|publisher=Fox News Radio|accessdate=2009-03-05}}</ref> and TV5.{{Where|date=July 2011}}
Later in 2007, as Bystrov was discussing the future of Shutdown Day with another friend, Ashutosh Rajekar, also a victim of excessive technology use, he realized that both had some interesting ideas to share regarding the future direction of Shutdown Day. Eventually, Denis, Nikolay and Ashutosh decided to team up to register as a non-profit organization in the province of Quebec.
In 2008, ''Shutdown Day'' was held on May 3. The message to turn off computers and engage in a day without technology was carried by Reuters wire services two days prior to the second annual event. Rajekar's message was now indicating that computers, televisions, and technology in general was having a negative effect on society.<ref name="Reuters 2008">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/lifestyleMolt/idUSN3044340220080501|title=Shutdown Day advocates say go offline, get outside|last=Mollins|first=Julie|date=May 1, 2008|publisher= Thomson Reuters|accessdate=2009-03-05}}</ref> Shortly prior to the event, Reuters carried a story encouraging users to step away from their technology for 24 hours. The estimated that the inaugural 2007 event had garnered over 50,000 participants. Many of the group had plans to visit parks, engage in cleaning up public areas, enjoy hiking, camping, and outdoor photography.<ref name="Reuters-2008">{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/lifestyleMolt/idUSN3044340220080501|title=Shutdown Day advocates say go offline, get outside|date=May 1, 2008|publisher=Thomson Reuters|accessdate=2009-03-11}}</ref>
=== 2009 === Shutdown day 2009 was held on May 2.<ref name="Shutdown day - home">{{cite web|url=http://www.shutdownday.org/|title=Shutdown Day|publisher=shutdownday.org|accessdate=2009-03-05}}</ref> The campaign started on March 1 and lasted through May 2, 2009. IT Wire reported that media organizations such as [[Fox News]], [[CNN]], [[The Toronto Sun]], The [[Washington Post]] were now carrying stories about Shutdown Day.<ref name="ITWire 2009">{{cite web|url=http://www.itwire.com/content/view/24587/545/|title=Shutdown Day 2009 |date=April 22, 2009|publisher=IT Wire|accessdate=2009-06-10}}</ref> C|Net reported that by April 23, almost 55,000 people had agreed to turn off their computers for 24 hours by going to shutdownday.org and clicking on the "yes, I can do it" link.<ref name="cnet 2009">{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-10784_3-6169942-7.html|title=Shutdown Day dares you to turn off your computer this Saturday|last=McCarthy|first=Caroline |work=C{{!}}Net|date=April 23, 2009|publisher=CBS Interactive Inc|accessdate=2009-06-10}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
