{{Infobox company | name = Soft On Demand | logo = Soft On Demand logo.svg | logo_size = 200px | type = | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = 1995 | founder = [[Ganari Takahashi]] | defunct = | location_city = [[Nakano, Tokyo]] | location_country = [[Japan]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = [[Pornography]] | products = [[Pornographic films]] | services = | market cap = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 128 | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = | footnotes = | intl = }} {{nihongo|'''Soft On Demand'''|ソフト・オン・デマンド|Sofuto On Demando}}, often known as '''SOD''', is a Japanese [[pornography|adult]] [[video]] group of companies which has its headquarters in the [[Nakano, Tokyo|Nakano]] ward of [[Tokyo]]. SOD was founded in December 1995<ref name="sodcorp">{{cite web|url=http://softondemand.jp/corporate/company/data.html|title=SOD Company Data|publisher=SOD|accessdate=2008-12-09|language=Japanese|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081217045257/http://softondemand.jp/corporate/company/data.html|archivedate=2008-12-17|df=}}</ref> by [[Ganari Takahashi]], who retired from the company in March 2005 and is currently working in agriculture.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ryann|last=Connell|title=Japan's king of porn gets his hands dirty once again -- on the farm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080514134536/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/culture/waiwai/archive/news/2007/02/20070226p2g00m0dm004000c.html|archivedate=May 14, 2008|url=http://mdn.mainichi.jp/culture/waiwai/archive/news/2007/02/20070226p2g00m0dm004000c.html|date=February 26, 2007|accessdate=2015-11-16}}</ref> The company is one of the largest adult video companies in Japan and is notable for its creative approach to adult videos.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lukeford.com/2008-01-25/some-real-information-on-the-japanese-dick-sucking-television-show/|title=SOME REAL INFORMATION ON THE JAPANESE DICK-SUCKING TELEVISION SHOW|accessdate=2009-03-04|date=January 25, 2008|last=Faynor|first=Scott|work=lukeford.com}}</ref>
==Company information==
===Finances=== In 2009, the company, under president Chie Sugawara (菅原 千恵), had 128 employees (27 male and 101 female) and a capital of 100 million yen (about US$1.1 million). For the fiscal year ending March 31, 2009, SOD had total sales of 14.9 billion yen (about US$165 million) and a profit of 670 million yen (about US$7.4 million). For 2007 the figures were sales of 13.5 billion yen (about US$120 million) and profit of 900 million yen (about US$8 million). SOD has been a fast-growing company since its foundation, going from sales of 300 million yen in 1996 to 1.5 billion in 1998 to 4.1 billion in 2000, 7.8 billion in 2003, and 9 billion in 2005.<ref name="sodcorp"/> In spite of its rapid growth, it was overtaken in sales volume in the early 2000s by rival AV producer [[Hokuto Corporation|Hokuto]], which also absorbed some of SOD's former companies. After peaking in 2008, Hokuto sales have plunged while annual income at SOD has stayed level at about 15 billion yen (about US$150 million) for the 2008-2010 period allowing it to become once again the largest adult video group in Japan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2012/02/26/national/av-stars-out-to-play-despite-hard-times/#.Ui9Rxn9ZiFy|title=AV stars out to play despite hard times|last=Bull|first=Brett|date=February 26, 2012|publisher=[[Japan Times]]|accessdate=2013-09-10}}</ref>
===Products=== One director has described their product this way: "SOD's porno is ridiculous. There's nothing really sordid about it" and "different to anything else in the porno world". Some of its most notable approaches have been quiz shows that tested the knowledge of [[AV idol|AV (adult video) actresses]] with challenging questions, CFNM ([[clothed female, naked male]]) videos that have women studying a man's penis (the "Uniforms, Undies and All Naked School Multi-Story" series), and plots where women are put under hypnosis. There have also been nude sports series, the senior citizen epic "All Naked Nursing Home for the Elderly", Company Sex Parties, Summer Festivals (a festival focused on penises and not to be confused with the actual Shinto festival dealing with fertility) and Sex Camps.<ref>{{cite news|title=Offbeat erotica pumps porno-maker into big time|last=Connell|first=Ryann|url=http://mdn.mainichi-msn.co.jp/waiwai/archive/news/2001/06/20010605p2g00m0dm999000c.html|work=[[Mainichi Shimbun]]|date=June 5, 2001|accessdate=2007-03-06}}{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} This source is no longer available but a copy of the article can be accessed at http://cid-88684d2bf683ba51.skydrive.live.com/self.aspx/mainichi/moto/2001/2001.06/Offbeat%20erotica%20pumps%20porno-maker%20into%20big%20time.pdf</ref>
One of their releases from May 2006, ''[[500 Person Sex]]'' (''500人SEX''),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dmm.co.jp/mono/dvd/-/detail/=/cid=1open0604/|title=人類史上初！！超ヤリまくり！イキまくり！500人SEX！！|accessdate=2008-12-10|language=Japanese|publisher=DMM|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090122030447/http://www.dmm.co.jp/mono/dvd/-/detail/%3D/cid%3D1open0604|archivedate=2009-01-22|df=}}</ref> features 250 couples having sex (apart from each other but in the same room) in an impressive synchronized way, and thus got some raised eyebrows from occidental adult sites.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ethnorotica.com/article/129/500-person-japanese-orgy|title=500 Person Japanese Orgy|accessdate=2007-03-06|date=June 13, 2006|work=ethnorotica.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090223230940/http://ethnorotica.com/article/129/500-person-japanese-orgy|archivedate=February 23, 2009|df=}}</ref> The video received a special jury award at the 2006 [[AV Open]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://allabout.co.jp/entertainment/adultvideo/closeup/CU20060712A/index2.htm|title=速報！AV OPEN結果発表 (Preliminary AV Open results Page 2)|publisher=All About|last=Otsubo|first=Kemuta|date=July 12, 2006|accessdate=2008-12-09|language=Japanese|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090129145455/http://allabout.co.jp/entertainment/adultvideo/closeup/CU20060712A/index2.htm|archivedate=January 29, 2009|df=}}</ref>
By 2003, SOD was releasing more than 1,000 adult video titles per year.<ref name="japaninc">{{cite web|url=http://www.japaninc.com/article.php?articleID=1188|title=The Ray Kroc of Adult Video|publisher=Japan Inc|accessdate=2009-04-01|last=McNeill|first=David|date=September 2003}}</ref> SOD also works with a number of companies in other areas and has thus become a group ([[zaibatsu]]) of companies mainly in the area of producing adult videos. Besides producing videos the company also produces condoms and lubricant lotions,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ec.sod.co.jp/ec/goods/f_main.jsp|title=Tenga|publisher=SOD|accessdate=2008-12-11|language=Japanese}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jbox.com/SEARCH/cure_rock|title=SOD Lotion ~ Emotion Type|publisher=JBOX|accessdate=2008-12-11}}</ref> PC games (aka [[hentai games]]), and adult [[anime]].<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100208082312/http://www.37c-binetsu.com/|archivedate=February 8, 2010|url=http://anime.sod.co.jp/index2.html|title=Anime On Demand|publisher=anime.sod.co.jp|accessdate=2015-11-16|language=Japanese}}</ref>
Outside of the adult area, SOD is also involved in producing softcore and genre movies,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/company/co0097320/|title=Soft on Demand [jp]|publisher=[[IMdB]]|accessdate=2008-12-11}}</ref> idol videos and TV programs. Among their mainstream movies, some have featured SOD AV actresses including the 2008 horror film ''[[Yoroi Samurai Zombie]]'' with [[Nana Natsume]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1298724/|title=Yoroi (2008)|accessdate=2008-10-20|publisher=[[IMDb]]}}</ref> and the 2006 comedy-drama ''[[Tokyo Daigaku Monogatari]]'', directed by [[Tatsuya Egawa]] and featuring Sasa Handa.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0781085/|title=Tôkyô Daigaku monogatari|accessdate=2009-04-29|publisher=[[IMDb]]}}</ref> A third entry was the 2014 science fiction film ''[[Danger Dolls]]'', with SOD star [[Mana Sakura]] making an appearance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scifijapan.com/articles/2014/05/14/godzilla-filmmaker-shusuke-kaneko-to-debut-sci-fi-action-film-danger-dolls-at-cannes/|title=Godzilla Filmmaker Shusuke Kaneko to Debut Sci-Fi Action Film DANGER DOLLS at Cannes|publisher=SciFi Japan|accessdate=2015-06-01}}</ref>
In 2004, the company announced plans to produce an adaptation of the [[Shougakukan]] ''[[Big Comic Original]]'' [[manga]] series ''Ajisai no Uta'' (''Song of Hydrangea'') as an [[original video animation]] (OAV) for a general audience.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.animaxis.com/en/zine/newsletter/view.asp?id=N001249|title=Major Adult Film Company to Produce Children's Anime|publisher=Animaxis.com|accessdate=2009-04-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080527013737/http://www.animaxis.com/en/zine/newsletter/view.asp?id=N001249|archivedate=2008-05-27|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2004-07-15/ajisai-no-uta-oav|title=Ajisai no Uta OAV|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=2009-04-04|date=July 15, 2004}}</ref> Volume 1 of the series was released in August 2004 and the fourth and final volume came out in December of that year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sod.co.jp/demand/anime/index.html|script-title=ja:あじさいの唄|publisher=SOD|accessdate=2009-04-04|language=Japanese|title=Archived copy|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090110100714/http://www.sod.co.jp/demand/anime/index.html|archive-date=2009-01-10|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
===SOD Create=== Internally, SOD outsources work to its individual units, original video production being done by SOD Create Inc. ({{nihongo2|SODクリエイト株式会社}}) headed by Daisuke Kasai ({{nihongo2|葛西 大祐}}).<ref name="sodcorp"/> This affiliate, founded in March 1999, was originally called {{nihongo|Hamlet|ハムレット|Hamuretto}} and changed its name to SOD Create in 2001.<ref name="sodcorp"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://homepage3.nifty.com/kurokami/years/years_1999.htm|title=1999|accessdate=2010-06-21|publisher=AV Research Laboratory|language=Japanese|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070318200334/http://homepage3.nifty.com/kurokami/years/years_1999.htm|archivedate=2007-03-18|df=}}</ref>
Package design for SOD is the realm of another division, SOD Artworks (SODアートワークス), founded in 2004, and under the leadership of Yoshino Toshimitsu ({{nihongo2|吉野敏充}}).<ref name="sodcorp"/>
====Labels==== In addition to the SOD label, SOD Create has produced videos under the following labels:<ref name="uncoinfo">{{cite web|url=http://urabon-navigator.com/av/studio/Soft%20On%20Demand|title=Soft On Demand Company Info|publisher=Urabon Navigator|accessdate=2011-11-02}}</ref> {{Div col}} * Eighteen * ON * Otis * Princess * SOD Cinderella * Senz * Star {{div col end}}
====Directors==== Directors who have worked at SOD include: {{Div col}} * Keita No.1 * [[Kei Morikawa]] * [[(Jo)Style|[Jo]Style]] * [[Goro Tameike]] * [[Tohjiro|TOHJIRO]] * Hajime Yarigasaki {{div col end}}
====Actresses==== Many well-known [[AV Idol]]s have performed for SOD: {{Div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Hotaru Akane]] * Risa Coda * Sasa Handa * [[Saori Hara]] * Hikari Hino * [[Rinako Hirasawa]] * Asuka Hoshino * [[Kaho Kasumi]] * [[Risa Kasumi]] * [[Mariko Kawana]] * Kotono * [[Hiromi Matsuura]] * [[Miyu Misaki]] * [[Tsugumi Nagasawa]] * [[Nana Natsume]] * [[Nao Oikawa]] * [[Mana Sakura]] * Yuko Sakurai * Sarah * [[Asami Sugiura]] * Tsubomi * Hime Tsukino * Akira Watase * [[Rico Yamaguchi]] * Sally Yoshino {{Div col end}}
====Series==== Important thematic series at SOD include:<ref name="uncoinfo"/> * Eighteen * Idol Semen ({{nihongo2|アイドルザーメン}}) * Masturbation Aid ({{nihongo2|のお手伝いしてあげる}}) * Super High-Class Soap Lady ({{nihongo2|超高級ソープ嬢}})
===STOP! STD=== For the past several years, SOD has run a campaign to bring attention to the rise of [[sexually transmitted disease]]s (STD) in Japan and to increase the use of condoms. The program, called STOP! STD, has used former SOD star [[Nana Natsume]] as a spokeswoman.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sod.co.jp/stopstd/|title=STOP! STD|publisher=SOD]|accessdate=2008-12-11|language=Japanese|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20050617041556/http://www.sod.co.jp/stopstd/|archivedate=2005-06-17|df=}}</ref>
===SOD AV Awards & the AV Open=== From 2002 to 2006, the company held the [[Japanese Adult Video Awards#SOD AV Awards (2002–2006)|SOD AV Awards]], an annual ceremony to present a series of awards to honor actresses, directors, and staff of companies in the SOD group. In 2006, the company also sponsored, along with [[Tokyo Sports]], a wider award contest called the [[AV Open]]. Sixteen companies competed for a total prize pool of 25 Million yen with the winner being decided by sales of the videos entered in the contest.<ref name="javnews">{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090513052400/http://www.superjav.com/blog/?p=95|archivedate=May 13, 2009|url=http://www.superjav.com/blog/?p=95|title=JAV News - Are There Japanese Adult Video Awards Like AVN Awards in USA?|publisher=JAV News|date=August 26, 2008|accessdate=2015-11-16}}</ref>
In the second year of the AV Open competition, 19 companies participated and the SOD entry won by a large margin. But it was subsequently discovered that SOD had used company funds to buy thousands of their own videos. SOD was disqualified and the discredited AV Open was replaced the next year by the [[Hokuto Corporation]] sponsored [[AV Grand Prix]].<ref name="javnews"/>
==Content Soft Association==
The Japanese AV industry has several different "ethics groups", which are voluntary organizations to assure adherence with Japanese pornography laws and to regulate content and copyrights. The earliest of these organizations was founded by the major AV companies in 1972 and is known in English as the [[Nihon Ethics of Video Association]] (NEVA) or in Japanese, Nippon Video Rinri Kyōkai (日本ビデオ倫理協会 "Japan Video Morality Association"), usually abbreviated as "Biderin" or "Viderin" (ビデ倫).<ref name="wired">{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/news/2004/04/63009?currentPage=all |title=Fix for Japan Pop-Culture Addicts |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |accessdate=2009-02-08 |date=April 12, 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.viderin.jp/|title=Nihon Ethics of Video Association|publisher=[[Nihon Ethics of Video Association]] |accessdate=2009-02-08|language=Japanese}}</ref> In response, SOD in 1996 began its own regulatory group known as the Media Ethics Association (Media Rinri Kyōkai or メディア倫理協会), usually abbreviated as Medirin(メディ倫). Medirin was composed of "indie" companies, independent AV studios which explored porn themes forbidden by NEVA rules and which used a smaller-pixeled censorship mosaic for their videos.<ref Name="wired"/> Medirin was re-organized in 2005 to form the Content Soft Association (CSA), called in Japanese Content Soft Kyōdō Kumiai (コンテンツ・ソフト協同組合 "Software Content Association"), to review and regulate adult videos and adult game software.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.contents-soft.or.jp/index.html |title=コンテンツ・ソフト協同組合 (Content Soft Association) |publisher=CSA |accessdate=2009-02-17 |language=Japanese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090225110445/http://contents-soft.or.jp/index.html |archivedate=2009-02-25 |df= }}</ref> The CSA has more than 65 members among AV producers comprising most of the SOD group and some other major companies. Members include:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.contents-soft.or.jp/member.html |title=CSA Members |publisher=CSA |accessdate=2009-02-17 |language=Japanese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090405171440/http://www.contents-soft.or.jp/member.html |archivedate=2009-04-05 |df= }}</ref>

{{other uses}} {{confusing|date=November 2009}}
A '''switcheroo''' is a sudden unexpected variation or reversal,<ref name="AmericanHeritageDictionary ">{{cite book |title= The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language |edition= Third |year= 1992 |publisher= [[Houghton Mifflin]] Company |isbn= 0-395-44895-6|page=1816| author = executive editor, Anne H. Soukhanov}}</ref> often for a humorous purpose.<ref name="TimeMagazine">{{cite magazine |magazine= Time Magazine |issue= |page=25 |title= Woody Allen: Rabbit Running |last= Kanfer |first= Vedi S. |url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,877848,00.html |accessdate= 2010-05-24 |date= 1972-07-03}}</ref> It is colloquially used in reference to an act of intentionally or unintentionally swapping two objects.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
As a [[comedic device]], this was a favorite of [[Woody Allen]]; for a time, he used so many switcheroos that friends referred to him as "Allen Woody."<ref name="TimeMagazine" /> Some of Allen's switcheroo gags include: *Carrying a sword on the street; in case of an attack it turned into a cane, so people would feel sorry for him *Carrying a bullet in his breast pocket; he claimed someone once threw a Bible at him and the bullet saved his life.
Another example comes from the film ''[[The Aristocrats (film)|The Aristocrats]]'', wherein [[Wendy Liebman]] pulls "the old switcheroo". Whereas the joke normally is narrated as a vulgar series of actions followed by the clean punch line, Liebman narrates a very aristocratic series of actions followed by a very vulgar punch line.<ref name="Aristocrats">{{cite book | title = The Aristocrats| last = Provenza| first =Paul | coauthors = | year = 2005| publisher = Mighty Cheese Productions| id = IMDB tt0436078}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yfaKld5ahfw|title=Video of Wendy Liebman's "Aristocrats" contribution}}</ref>
In his book ''[[Gödel, Escher, Bach]]'', [[Douglas Hofstadter]] names one of the rules in his version of [[propositional calculus]] the '''Switcheroo Rule''', apparently in honour of an Albanian railroad engineer, name Q. Q. Switcheroo, who "worked in logic on the siding".<ref name="GEB">{{cite book | title = Gödel, Escher, Bach | last = Hofstadter | first = Douglas R. | coauthors = | year = 1979 | publisher = Basic Books |page=187}}</ref> This is in reality the ''[[Material implication (rule of inference)|material implication]]''.

'''Terence "Terry" Hall''' (20 November 1926 – 3 April 2007) was an English [[ventriloquist]]. He appeared regularly on television with his puppet, '''Lenny the Lion''', whose catchphrase was "Aw, don't embawass me!" Hall is credited with having been one of the first ventriloquists to use a non-human puppet.<ref name="Guardian">[https://www.theguardian.com/obituaries/story/0,,2090807,00.html Obituary], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 30 May 2007]</ref>
==Biography== Hall was born in [[Chadderton]], [[Lancashire]], where his parents ran a [[working men's club]].<ref name="Guardian"/> He was educated at St Patrick's School in [[Oldham]] and at De La Salle College in [[Pendleton, Greater Manchester|Pendleton]], [[County Borough of Salford|Salford]]. Hall initially worked as a ventriloquist with a boy dummy, named Mickey Finn, and won a talent show aged 15.
Hall created Lenny the Lion in 1954 after he visited the zoo while working at the [[summer season]] in [[Blackpool]]. Lenny was made from an old fox fur and [[papier-mâché]], with a golf ball for the nose. He originally had a mouthful of fearsome teeth, but they were removed at the suggestion of singer [[Anne Shelton (singer)|Anne Shelton]]{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} to avoid scaring children in the audience.
Hall and Lenny first appeared on BBC Television in 1956, in a variety show entitled ''Dress Rehearsal'' that also signalled [[Eric Sykes]]'s television debut. The ''Lenny the Lion Show'' ran on from 1957 to 1960, followed by ''Lenny's Den'' in 1959 to 1961, and the pop music show ''Pops and Lenny'' in 1962 to 1963. In 1958 Bill Mevin created a comic strip based on ''Lenny the Lion''.<ref>https://www.lambiek.net/artists/m/mevin_bill.htm</ref> Hall visited the United States in 1958, making his debut on ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'' with Lenny that year. Throughout the 1960s, Hall and Lenny appeared on stage in Blackpool and on television. [[The Beatles]] made one of their early TV appearances in a 1963 episode of ''Pops and Lenny'', singing "[[From Me to You]]" and "[[Please Please Me (song)|Please, Please Me]]." [[David Bowie]]'s father, Hayward Jones, worked on the show, and launched the Lenny the Lion Fan Club. Lenny advertised [[Cadbury|Trebor]] mints for three years. Hall released a single, "Lenny's Bath Time", in 1963.
In spite of the fact that Hall was a staunch [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] fan, during the 1957–58 English football season, Hall took Lenny to [[The Old Den|the Den (old)]] which was then the home of [[Millwall F.C.]] and allowed Lenny to pose with his "fellow Lions" for publicity shots, much to the delight of all present in the ground.<ref name="Bethel">Bethel, Chris. ''Millwall Football Club 1940–2001'' Tempus Publishing Ltd. p44. {{ISBN|0-7524-2187-5}}</ref>
Hall and Lenny continued to work in variety through the 1970s, appearing on television in programmes such as ''[[Crackerjack (TV series)|Crackerjack]]''<ref name="Guardian"/> and ''[[3-2-1]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SkG9yXKbKmA|title=3-2-1 - 'Hollywood' (1978)|first=|last=gbgameshows|date=31 October 2012|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref> From 1977 to 1980, Hall regularly appeared in the educational television programme ''Reading With Lenny''. He wrote the ''Kevin the Kitten'' series of children's reading books which accompanied the series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadcastforschools.co.uk/site/Reading_with_Lenny|title=Reading with Lenny - BroadcastForSchools.co.uk|website=www.broadcastforschools.co.uk}}</ref>
Hall married twice. He had two daughters from his first marriage. He married a second time in 1980, to dance teacher Denise Francis. He suffered from [[Alzheimer's disease]] in later life, and died in 2007 in [[Coventry]] aged 80. [[Dr. Harry Brünjes|Dr Harry Brünjes]], a long-standing family friend, gave the eulogy at the service.
==References== <references />
==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=0356149|name=Terry Hall}} *{{IMDb name|id=1573158|name=Lenny the Lion}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070326003652/http://www.televisionheaven.co.uk/kids3.htm Lenny the Lion at TelevisionHeaven.com] *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/coventry_warwickshire/6544083.stm Children's entertainer Hall dies], [[BBC News]], 11 April 2007 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070930165333/http://news.independent.co.uk/people/obituaries/article2441965.ece Obituary], ''[[The Independent]]'', 12 April 2007 *[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?view=DETAILS&grid=&xml=/news/2007/04/12/db1202.xml Obituary], ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', 12 April 2007 *[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article1652124.ece Obituary], ''[[The Times]]'', 14 April 2007

{{Infobox album | name = The County Hound 2 | type = Studio | artist = [[Ca$his]] | cover = TheCountyHound2.jpg | border = yes | alt = | released = {{start date|2013|10|15}} | recorded = 2013 | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]], [[gangsta rap]] | length = 66:14 | label = Bogish Brand Entertainment | producer = [[Cashis]] <small>([[Executive producer#Music|exec.]])</small>, Rikanatti <small>(also exec.)</small>, Cin-A-Matik, [[Eminem]], The Punisher, Lil' Lyss, R&D, 1Down, Steve E | prev_title = The Art of Dying | prev_year = 2012 | next_title = Euthanasia | next_year = 2014 | misc = {{Singles | name = The County Hound 2 | type = studio | single1 = Layin' in the Cut | single1date = April 30, 2013 | single2 = Mind on Money | single2date = May 14, 2013 | single3 = Imma Hustla | single3date = July 1, 2013 | single4 = Look at Me | single4date = August 19, 2013 | single5 = Hi | single5date = August 21, 2013 | single6 = Take the Pain | single6date = June 17, 2014 | single7 = Bright Lights | single7date = July 1, 2014 | single8 = Red | single8date = July 29, 2014 }} }}
'''''The County Hound 2''''' is the second [[studio album]] by American rapper [[Cashis]], who also served as executive producer. It was released independently on October 15, 2013, by his label Bogish Brand Entertainment. It serves as the sequel to his debut [[Extended Play|EP]] ''[[The County Hound EP]]'', which was released on May 22, 2007 by [[Shady Records]] and [[Interscope Records]]. The album features [[guest appearance]]s by [[Crooked I]] from [[Slaughterhouse (group)|Slaughterhouse]], [[Obie Trice]], [[Mistah F.A.B.]], Kuniva from [[D12]], [[King Los]], K. Young, [[Rostrum Records|Boaz]], and [[Demrick]] among others. [[Hip hop production|Production]] for the album took place during 2013, and was handled primarily by Rikanatti and [[Eminem]] among others. The album was supported by eight singles — "Layin' in the Cut", "Mind on Money", "Imma Hustla", "Look at Me", "Hi", "Take the Pain", "Bright Lights" and "Red". It was also met with positive reviews from [[music critic]]s.
== Background == Just prior to the release of his debut album ''The Art of Dying'', [[Cashis]] revealed he had already begun to work on his second studio album ''Euthanasia'', which he claimed was 65% done in September 2012. He also revealed that it would feature production from [[Jake One]] and [[Eminem]], also while projecting a May 2013 release for the project.<ref name="www.hiphopdx.com">{{cite web | last = | first = | title = Cashis Details Album Delay, Relives Moment Eminem Offered To Help Him With Drug Rehab | url = http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/interviews/id.1959/title.cashis-details-album-delay-relives-moment-eminem-offered-to-help-him-with-drug-rehab | publisher = HipHopDX | date = | accessdate = 27 October 2012 }}</ref> Upon the release of the first single in May 2013, the album was renamed ''The County Hound 2''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/singles/id.24285/title.Cashis-Layin+In+The+Cut+%5BProd.+Eminem+%26+Rikanatti%5D |title=Cashis - Layin In The Cut [Prod. Eminem & Rikanatti] | New Hip Hop Music & All The New Rap Songs 2011 |publisher=HipHop DX |date=2013-05-02 |accessdate=2013-10-15}}</ref>
On September 28, 2013, Cashis revealed the cover art and track list to the album, also announcing a release date of October 15, 2013. He also revealed previously unannounced guest appearances on the album to come from [[Rostrum Records|Boaz]], and [[Demrick]] among others, with the album's production to be primarily handled by him and his frequent collaborator Rikanatti (who they both executive produce and handle the A&R Direction for the album), with Eminem also producing significantly on the album.<ref>{{cite web|last=Burgess |first=Omar |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.25582/title.eminem-to-produce-four-tracks-on-ca-his-the-county-hound-2-/ |title=Eminem To Produce Four Tracks On Ca$his' "The County Hound 2" | Get The Latest Hip Hop News, Rap News & Hip Hop Album Sales |publisher=HipHop DX |date=2013-09-28 |accessdate=2013-10-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ballerstatus.com/2013/09/28/cashis-readies-county-hound-2-eminem-production/ |title=Cashis Readies 'County Hound 2' With Eminem Production |publisher=BallerStatus.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-15}}</ref> In total, Eminem produced four tracks, such as the first single "Layin' in the Cut", and three more songs, such as "Thru the Glass", "Ask About Me" and "Cigarello".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fashionnstyle.com/articles/11841/20130930/eminem-new-album-2013-studio-mmlp2-song-list-will-not-leak-release-date-berzerk-rapper-producer-cashis-skylar-grey-video.htm |title=Eminem New Album 2013: Studio Says ‘MMLP2’ Song List Will Not Leak Before Release Date; ‘Berzerk’ Rapper Turns Producer For Ca$his, Skylar Grey [VIDEO] : Celebrity : Fashion & Style |publisher=Fashionnstyle.com |date=2013-09-30 |accessdate=2013-10-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mstarz.com/articles/19675/20130930/eminem-new-album-2013-mmlp2-rapper-produces-four-songs-cashis-new-album-the-county-hound-2-before-nov-5-release-date-tracklist-video.htm |title=Eminem New Album 2013: 'MMLP2' Rapper Produces Four Songs on Ca$his New Album 'The County Hound 2' Before Nov. 5 Release Date [TRACKLIST/VIDEO] : Music News |publisher=Mstarz |date=2013-09-30 |accessdate=2013-10-15}}</ref>
== Release and promotion == On December 25, 2012, Cashis released the first mixtape in promotion of the album titled ''Loose Cannon'', which was previously going to be the title of his third studio album.<ref>{{cite web|author=Title Artist Name |url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/cashis-loose-cannon-mixtape.71900.html |title=Ca$his Mixtapes - Loose Cannon |publisher=Hotnewhiphop.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-25}}</ref>
In July 2013, Cashis announced that he was also working on his next mixtape ''The Loose Cannon 2'', which would contain mostly freestyles.<ref name="hiphopdx1">{{cite web|last=Connor |first=Martin |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/interviews/id.2138/title.ca-his-discloses-ongoing-writing-agreement-with-shady-records |title=Ca$his Discloses Ongoing Writing Agreement With Shady Records | Rappers Talk Hip Hop Beef & Old School Hip Hop |publisher=HipHop DX |date=2013-07-03 |accessdate=2013-10-15}}</ref> On October 14, 2013, Cashis released the Eminem-produced song "Cigarello" via [[SoundCloud]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.missinfo.tv/index.php/eminem-cashsis-cigarello/ |title=Exclusive: Eminem Drops a Beat for Ca$his "Cigarello" |publisher=MissInfo.tv |date= |accessdate=2013-10-15}}</ref> The album was released digitally on October 15, 2013, with physical copies to be released two weeks later.<ref>{{cite tweet|user=TheRealCashis|author=King Ca$his|number=389982600774688768|date=15 October 2013|title=Hard copies are, in 2 weeks, show your support on itunes or amazon or any digital outlet .. I appreciate it}}</ref> It was also released for free stream on its digital release day for a limited time.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ahmadi |first=Kevin |url=http://respect-mag.com/album-stream-cahis-the-county-hound-2/ |title=Album Stream: Ca$his – The County Hound 2 : RESPECT |publisher=Respect-mag.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://stupiddope.com/2013/10/15/cahis-county-hound-2-album-stream-new-music/ |title=Ca$his – County Hound 2 (Album Stream) | New Music |publisher=stupidDOPE.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-15}}</ref>
On October 31, 2013, Cashis announced that he would be releasing a high quantity of music videos for songs from the album soon.<ref>{{cite tweet|user=TheRealCashis|author=King Ca$his|number=396008673194942464|date=31 October 2013|title=Get ready for a flood of visuals from Countyhound 2. Yall are supporting the album to the max. I appreciate the support! #Bogish}}</ref> Following the album's release, Cashis and [[Demrick]] toured through the rest of 2013.<ref name="hiphopdx1" />
== Singles == On April 30, 2013, Cashis released the first single from his newly titled second studio album ''The County Hound 2'', titled "Layin in the Cut" which was produced by Eminem and Rikanatti.<ref>{{cite web|author=Steve Raze (@SteveRaze) |url=http://allhiphop.com/2013/05/01/cahis-layin-in-the-cut-prod-by-eminem-rikanatti/ |title=Ca$his "Layin In The Cut" Prod by Eminem & Rikanatti |publisher=AllHipHop.com |date=2013-05-01 |accessdate=2013-10-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/singles/id.24285/title.Cashis-Layin+In+The+Cut+%5BProd.+Eminem+%26+Rikanatti%5D |title=Cashis - Layin In The Cut [Prod. Eminem & Rikanatti] | New Hip Hop Music & All The New Rap Songs 2011 |publisher=HipHop DX |date=2013-05-02 |accessdate=2013-08-25}}</ref> The music video for "Layin' in the Cut" was released on August 8, 2013, which also featured a preview of the music video for "Look at Me".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/08/video-premiere-cashis-layin-in-the-cut |title=Ca$his "Layin' In The Cut" Video |publisher=Complex |date=2013-08-08 |accessdate=2013-10-11}}</ref> The second single from the album titled, "Mind on Money" was released to iTunes on May 16, 2013. The song features rappers Kuniva from D12, [[Obie Trice]] and Dirty Mouth.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/05/premiere-cahis-f-kuniva-obie-trice-and-dirty-mouth-mind-on-my-money-money-on-my-mind |title=Premiere: Ca$his f/ Kuniva, Obie Trice, and Dirty Mouth "Mind on My Money (Money on My Mind)" |publisher=Complex |date=2013-05-16 |accessdate=2013-08-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Steve Raze (@SteveRaze) |url=http://allhiphop.com/2013/05/16/cahis-ft-kuniva-obie-trice-dirty-mouth-mind-on-money-prod-by-rikanatti-cin-a-matik-1/ |title=Ca$his Ft. Kuniva, Obie Trice & Dirty Mouth "Mind On Money" Prod by Rikanatti & Cin-a-Matik 1 |publisher=AllHipHop.com |date=2013-05-16 |accessdate=2013-10-11}}</ref> On June 21, 2013, Cashis released a music video for his verse on "Mind on Money", also previewing the album's third single "Imma Hustla".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/06/video-premiere-cahis-mind-on-money |title=Video Premiere: Ca$his "Mind on Money" |publisher=Complex |date=2013-06-21 |accessdate=2013-10-15}}</ref>
On July 1, 2013, Cashis released "Imma Hustla" featuring [[Crooked I]] from Slaughterhouse and Sullee J, for digital download as the album's third single.<ref>{{cite web |author=Whitefolks |url=http://defsounds.com/hip-hop-singles/cahis-ft-crooked-i-sullee-j-imma-hustla/ |title=Ca$his Ft. Crooked I & Sullee J: Imma Hustla |publisher=Def Sounds |date=2013-07-09 |accessdate=2013-08-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130712070610/http://defsounds.com/hip-hop-singles/cahis-ft-crooked-i-sullee-j-imma-hustla/ |archivedate=2013-07-12 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://stupiddope.com/2013/07/09/cahis-crooked-i-sullee-j-imma-hustla-new-music/ |title=Ca$his, Crooked I & Sullee J – Imma Hustla | New Music |publisher=stupidDOPE.com |date=2013-07-09 |accessdate=2013-10-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/singles/id.24922/title.Cashis+f.+Crooked+I+%26+Sullee+J-Imma+Hustla |title=Cashis f. Crooked I & Sullee J - Imma Hustla | New Hip Hop Music & All The New Rap Songs 2011 |publisher=HipHop DX |date=2013-07-09 |accessdate=2013-10-11}}</ref> On September 30, 2013, Cashis released the remix to "Imma Hustla" featuring Crooked I, [[Mistah F.A.B.]], Roccett and Goldie Gold.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.djbooth.net/index/tracks/review/cashis-imma-hustle-wc-rmx |title=Ca$his ft. Crooked I, Mistah FAB, Roccett & Goldie Gold - Imma Hustla (West Coast Remix) | Listen & Download |publisher=Djbooth.net |date= |accessdate=2013-10-15}}</ref> Then on August 19, 2013 he released the fourth single from ''The Country Hound 2'', entitled "Look at Me" featuring [[King Los]], K Young and B. Todd.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/08/premiere-cashis-f-king-los-k-young-b-todd-look-at-me |title=Ca$his, King Los, K Young, B Todd "Look At Me" |publisher=Complex |date=2013-08-19 |accessdate=2013-08-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.djbooth.net/index/tracks/review/cashis-look-at-me |title=Ca$his ft. Los, K-Young & B Todd - Look at Me | Listen |publisher=Djbooth.net |date= |accessdate=2013-10-11}}</ref> Two days later, Cashis premiered the track "Hi" from the album.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/08/listen-cashis-hi |title=Ca$his "Hi" |publisher=Complex |date=2013-08-21 |accessdate=2013-10-15}}</ref> Later that day, it was released to iTunes as the album's fifth single.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/hi-single/id692349045 |title=iTunes - Music - Hi - Single by Ca$his |publisher=Itunes.apple.com |date=2013-08-21 |accessdate=2013-10-15}}</ref>
== Critical reception == {{Album ratings |rev1 = [[HipHopDX]] |rev1Score = {{rating|3|5}}<ref name="hiphopdxreview">{{cite web|last=Burgess |first=Omar |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/album-reviews/id.2170/title.ca-his-the-county-hound-2 |title=Ca$his - The County Hound 2 |publisher=HipHop DX |date= |accessdate=2013-10-19}}</ref> }} ''The County Hound 2'' was met with generally positive reviews from [[music critic]]s. Omar Burgess of [[HipHopDX]] gave it a positive review saying, "Ultimately, ''The County Hound 2'' serves as a welcome return for loyal Ca$his fans. Name recognition from his Shady days, production from Eminem and some of the lighter singles will likely draw in newcomers. Repeated listens offer a bottom-heavy album; the first half of which both informs and sometimes detracts from the latter portion with trite subject matter. But there’s enough raw talent here to impress a diverse cross section of fans, and when Ca$his chooses depth over accessibility he’s still scary good in the booth."<ref name="hiphopdxreview"/>

{{Infobox book | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = The Language of Music | image = The Language of Music (theory book).jpg | caption = Cover of the 2012 Hal Leonard Publishing edition | author = [[Tom Brooks (music producer)|Tom Brooks]] | country = United States | language = English | subject = [[Music]] | published = 2012 | media_type = Print | pages = 254 | isbn = 978-1-45840-294-3 | website = tombrooksmusic.com--> }}
'''''The Language of Music''''' (2012) is a contemporary [[music theory]] book written by [[Tom Brooks (music producer)|Tom Brooks]] and published by [[Hal Leonard Publishing]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.halleonard.com/product/viewproduct.action?itemid=333251&subsiteid=66&|title=The Language of Music, Worship Musician Presents - Hal Leonard Online|website=www.halleonard.com|accessdate=1 September 2017}}</ref> The book explains principles used in modern music starting at a foundational level (Basic Building Blocks of Music) and progressing to topics such as [[Chord (music)|Chord Building]], Transposition, [[Cadence (music)|Cadences]], [[Mode (music)|Modes]], and Chord Substitution.<ref>https://www.christianbook.com/language-music-practical-theory-worshipping-musician/9781458402943/pd/333251#CBD-PD-Description</ref> The book also demonstrates concepts using well known pop/rock song examples.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Language_of_Music.html?id=AWNCtwAACAAJ|title=The Language of Music|first=Tom|last=Brooks|date=1 July 2013|publisher=Hal Leonard Books|accessdate=1 September 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref> It is used as a textbook by college level music theory programs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hiu.edu/undergraduate-on-campus/academics/colleges/pacific-christian-college-of-ministry-and-biblical-studies/worship-arts|title=Hope International University - Bachelor of Music - Music & Worship Arts|first=Caliber Media Group,|last=Inc.|website=www.hiu.edu|accessdate=1 September 2017}}</ref> The book also includes a quick start guide, a chord library appendix, and a DVD with 38 video tutorials by the author.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jwpepper.com/The-Language-of-Music/10395414.item#/|title=The Language of Music by Tom Brooks- J.W. Pepper Sheet Music|first=J.W. Pepper and|last=Son|website=www.jwpepper.com|accessdate=1 September 2017}}</ref>
==Table of Contents==
1. The Basic Building Blocks of Music
2. Foundational Structures
3. Basic Harmony
4. The Framework
5. Chord “Personalities”
6. The Minor Scale
7. The Anatomy of a Chord Chart
8. Harmony: The Next Step
9. Chord Relationships 201
10. Scales: Beyond Major and Minor
11. Harmony: Outside the Box
12. Making Music “Musical”: From Theory to Live Performance
==Topics== The book is divided into 38 individual Lessons covering topics such as pitch, rhythm, [[time signatures]], the [[major scale]], [[key signatures]], the [[Circle of Fifths]], triad inversion, and [[7th chord|7th chords]]. The writing is geared toward pop/rock. Areas of focus include familiar pop chord progressions, chord symbols, reading & writing modern chord charts and the [[Nashville Number System]]. More advanced topics include modulation, the [[blues scale]], extended chords, altered chords, and borrowed chords used in jazz and gospel music, plus practice and rehearsal tips.
==Reception== Singer-Songwriter [[Don Moen]] of [[Integrity Music]] is quoted as saying, “The Language of Music takes the mystery out of music theory and explains it in a very clear, practical, straightforward way”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://donmoen.com/about/|title=About - Don Moen - Praise & Worship Leader|website=donmoen.com|accessdate=1 September 2017}}</ref> Musician [[Abraham Laboriel]] states, “…more than just practical music theory, this book is an outpouring of the heart and spirit…”. Rick Muchow, Music Director of [[Saddleback Church]] says, “…this is a guidebook to modern music theory that every musician needs”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rickmuchow.com/about/|title=About|website=rickmuchow.com|accessdate=1 September 2017}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{Official website|https://www.tombrooksmusic.com}} TomBrooksMusic.com
{{DEFAULTSORT:Language of Music, The}} [[Category:2012 books]] [[Category:Music theory]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=June 2009}} [[File:Hank Sanicola, Toots Shor Frank Sinatra 1947.jpg|thumb|[[Hank Sanicola]], Toots Shor, and [[Frank Sinatra]] in 1947]] '''Bernard "Toots" Shor''' (May 6, 1903 – January 23, 1977)<ref>{{cite news|last=Anderson|first=Dave|title=Toots Shor, 73, 'Saloonkeeper' and Host, Dies|work=The New York Times|date=24 Jan 1977|page=1}}</ref> was best known as the proprietor of a legendary saloon and restaurant, [[Toots Shor's Restaurant]], in [[Manhattan]]. He ran three different establishments under that name, but his first – and most renowned – was located at 51 West 51st Street. He was known as a saloonkeeper, friend, and confidant to some of [[New York City|New York]]'s biggest celebrities during that era.
Shor was born in [[Philadelphia]] to Orthodox Jewish parents – his father of Austrian descent from Germany and his mother from Russia. He and his two older sisters were raised in a home above the family candy store in [[South Philadelphia]]. When Shor was 15 years old, his mother was killed by an automobile while she sat on the stoop outside their home. His father committed suicide five years later. Shor attended the [[Drexel Institute of Technology]] and the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]] before working as a traveling shirt-and-underwear [[salesman]].
==First restaurant==
Shor went to [[New York City]] in 1930 and found employment as a bouncer at the Five O'Clock Club, which served as his introduction to celebrities. He later worked at several other nightspots: The Napoleon Club, Lahiff's Tavern, the Ball & Chain, the Madison Royale, and Leon & Eddie's. He became a man about town in Manhattan after opening his own restaurant, [[Toots Shor's]], at 51 West 51st Street. While the food there was known to be "nuttin' fancy" – standard American, sports-bar fare such as shrimp cocktail, steak, baked potato – the establishment became well known for who frequented there and the manner in which Shor interacted with them.
Shor was a raconteur and a master of the "needle," jibes or quips directed at the famous. Celebrity alone was not enough to receive first-class service in Shor's restaurant. According to [[David Halberstam]] in his book ''The Summer of '49'', guests had to observe the unwritten "code" which prevailed in Shor's establishment. [[Charlie Chaplin]], who was not privy to that code, was made to wait in line. When Chaplin complained, Shor told him to entertain the others who were waiting in line. One day, Hollywood boss [[Louis B. Mayer]] complained about waiting twenty minutes for a table and said, "I trust the food will be worth all that waiting." Shor replied: "It'll be better'n some of your crummy pictures I stood in line for." Once while standing outside his restaurant with [[Frank Sinatra]] and a crowd of screaming fans being held back by police, Toots pulled out a dollar bill out of his pocket and said to Frank, "Here, kid, go across the street and buy me a paper." At the Opera with friends during the intermission Toots declared, "I bet I'm the only bum in this joint that doesn't know how this thing ends."
In one incident, Shor outdrank comedian [[Jackie Gleason]], famously leaving Gleason on the floor to prove the point. (At Toots' funeral, the coffin had a spray of red roses with a card which read, "Save a Table for 2," signed: Jackie Gleason.)
Shor cultivated his celebrity following by giving them unqualified admiration, loyal friendship, and a kind of happy, boozy, old-fashioned male privacy. Those whom Shor really liked were called "crum-bums". Shor reputedly said that he didn’t care if he was a millionaire – so long as he could live like one.
==Second restaurant==
In 1959, Shor sold the lease for his [[51st Street (Manhattan)|51st Street]] restaurant for $1.5 million to [[William Zeckendorf]].<ref>''[[Toots (film)|Toots]]''</ref> The following year, he opened at a new location at 33 West [[52nd Street (Manhattan)|52nd Street]] and tried to emulate the decor and atmosphere of the original. The then–Chief Justice, [[Earl Warren]], considered Toots one of his closest friends. "The Chief" showed up to be photographed with a shovel full of dirt when Toots broke ground on Toots' 52nd street "joint".
==Third restaurant==
In 1971, authorities padlocked the doors of the 52nd Street restaurant for nonpayment of federal, state, and local taxes totaling $269,516. He vowed to open again in three weeks, but 18 months passed before his restaurant at 5 East [[54th Street (Manhattan)|54th Street]] opened. For a variety of reasons, however, his famous clientele never returned with their former regularity.
==Personal life==
Shor and his wife Marion ("Baby") lived for many years in a 12-room double apartment at 480 Park Avenue where they raised their four children named Bari Ellen, Kerry, Rory and Tracey. Tracey, who was Toots' youngest daughter and a late arrival, was taken in and raised by his friends, comedian Bob Hope and his wife Dolores, who was her Godmother at birth and eventually her legal guardian.
During his final years, they lived at the Drake Hotel. He died at age 73, ending a six-week stay in New York University Hospital.
Shor's financial affairs were usually shaky at best thanks to a cavalier attitude toward the IRS, coupled with a generous nature; debts were frequently forgiven for friends who had fallen on hard times, and drinks and meals were comped on a regular basis. Although indigent at the time of death, Shor expressed no regrets, stating that he started out broke and figured it was OK to go out that way as well.
In 1950, Shor was the subject of a three-part biography published in ''[[The New Yorker]]'' entitled "Toots's World" and written by John Bainbridge, who later combined them into a book. Twenty years later another biography, ''Toots'', was written by Hearst columnist [[Bob Considine]]. In 2006, the biographical documentary ''[[Toots (documentary film)|Toots]]'', in which his granddaughter Kristi Jacobson profiled his life,<ref name="Barra">[http://www.americanheritage.com/articles/magazine/ah/2006/6/2006_6_16.shtml Allen Barra]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} "Documentary: The Incomparable Toots" ''American Heritage'', Nov./Dec. 2006.</ref> premiered at the [[Tribeca Film Festival]]. It took "Best Film" at the [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum]]'s first annual film festival on November 12, 2006.<ref>[http://www.happynews.com/news/11142006/films-recognized-cooperstown-inaugural-baseball-hall-fame-film-festival.htm "Films Recognized at Inaugural Baseball Hall of Fame Film Fest," National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum press release, Wednesday, November 15, 2006.]</ref> ''Toots'' was released to theaters in the fall of 2007.
Bob Broderick, long time friend and Manager of Toots Shor's, was quoted in [[The Record (Troy, NY)|The Record]], NY. 4/20/1968 saying,"Having Toots Shor for a friend and Margaret for a wife is about all a man can ask for out of this life."
From the 1950s-1960s, Shor was an occasional guest on television programs, including twice appearing on the CBS panel show ''[[What's My Line?]]'' as well as on programs such as ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]'' and ''[[The Red Skelton Show]]''.<ref name="tvprograms">{{IMDb name|1176590|Toots Shor}}</ref>
Shor was portrayed by [[Vlasta Vrána]] in ''[[Gleason (2002 film)|Gleason]]'', a 2002 television biopic about the life of [[Jackie Gleason]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Gallo|first=Phil|title=Gleason|date=10 October 2002|publisher=''[[Variety (magazine)]]''|url=https://variety.com/2002/tv/reviews/gleason-1200545545/|accessdate=10 December 2017}}</ref>

{{about|the aerial apparatus|other uses|Trapeze (disambiguation)}} [[Image:Trapeze Artists in Circus.jpg|thumb|right|Trapeze artists, in lithograph by Calvert Litho. Co., 1890.]]
A '''trapeze''' is a short horizontal bar hung by ropes or metal straps from a support. It is an [[aerialist|aerial]] apparatus commonly found in [[circus (performing arts)|circus performances]]. Trapeze acts may be static, spinning (rigged from a single point), swinging or flying, and may be performed solo, double, triple or as a group act. <ref name=NICA>{{cite web|url=http://www.nica.com.au/dictionary|publisher=National Institute of Circus Arts|title=Circus Dictionary|accessdate=October 1, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719162832/http://www.nica.com.au/dictionary|archivedate=July 19, 2011|df=}}</ref>
==History== The art of trapeze performance was developed by [[Jules Léotard]], a young French [[Acrobatics|acrobat]] and [[aerialist]], in [[Toulouse]] in the mid-1800s. He invented the flying trapeze, practising over his father's swimming pool.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/j/jules-leotard/|title=Jules Léotard|last=|first=|website=Victoria and Albert Museum|access-date=2016-04-12}}</ref>
== Types of trapeze ==
* [[Static trapeze]] refers to a trapeze act in which the performer moves around the bar and ropes, performing a wide range of movements including balances, drops, hangs while the bar itself stays generally static. The difficulty on a static trapeze is making every move look effortless. It is like dance, in that most people of a reasonable level of strength can get onto the trapeze bar for the first time and perform some basic tricks, but an experienced artist will do them with much more grace and style. * [[Swinging trapeze]] (or swinging single trapeze) refers to an act performed on a trapeze swinging in a forward - backward motion. The performer builds up swing from a still position, and uses the momentum of the swing to execute the tricks. Usually tricks on a swinging trapeze are thrown on the peaks of the swing and involve dynamic movements that require precise timing. Most of the tricks begin with the performer sitting or standing on the bar and end with the performer catching the bar in his/her hands or in an ankle hang (hanging by the ankles by bracing them between the rope and the bar). This act requires a great deal of strength, grace, and flexibility.<ref name=NICA /> The trapeze bar is weighted and often has cable inside the supporting ropes for extra strength to withstand the dynamic forces of the swing. * [[Flying trapeze]] refers to a trapeze act where a performer, or "flyer," grabs the trapeze bar and jumps off a high platform, or pedestal board, so that gravity creates the swing. The swing's parts are the "force out" (sometimes called the "cast out") at the far end of the first swing, the beat back and the rise (also known as "seven") as the performer swings back above the pedestal board, and then the trick is thrown at the far end of the second swing. The performer often releases the bar and is caught by another performer, the "catcher," who hangs by his or her knees on another trapeze, or sometimes on a cradle, which can be either stationary or also swinging. People of any size are able to execute basic trapeze maneuvers. Flying trapeze is generally done over a net, or occasionally over water. In the UK, many outdoor education centres offer an activity known as 'leap of faith'. This activity invites participants to climb to the top of a narrow pole and jump, arms outstretched, to grab a trapeze bar. Similar to the flying trapeze, gravity creates the swing. In this type of activity, participants are attached via rope and harness and an added challenge to get your legs over the trapeze can be included. * [[Washington trapeze]] (also known as head trapeze or heavy trapeze) refers to a variation on static and swinging trapeze where the aerialist performs various headstand skills on the bar, which is typically much heavier than a normal trapeze bar and has a small (about 4-inch round) headstand platform on it. The trapeze is supported by wire cables rather than ropes, and the apparatus will often be lifted and lowered during the act.<ref name=NICA /> * [[Dance trapeze]] (also known as [[single-point trapeze]]) refers to a trapeze used by many [[modern dance]] companies in [[aerial dance]]. The ropes of the trapeze are often both attached to a single [[swivel]], allowing the trapeze to spin in either small or large circles. * [[Double trapeze]] (also known as the French trapeze) is a variation on the static trapeze, and features two performers working together on the same trapeze to perform figures and bear each other's weight. It can also be performed swinging, in which case the act is called "swinging double trapeze."<ref name=NICA /> * [[Multiple trapeze]][[File:CJ_triple_trapeze_May.jpg|thumb|300px|Triple trapeze]] refers to a number of different shapes and sizes of trapeze, including double trapeze, [[triple trapeze]] and larger multiples designed for use by multiple simultaneous flyers. Shaped trapezes are apparatuses that can take virtually any shape imaginable. * Duplex Trapeze refer to any trapeze with two layers of hand bars, one on top of the other such that acrobats can jump from the upper and land (or be caught by a catcher) on the lower.
==Further reading== * Sharon McCutcheon, Geoff Perrem. ''Circus in Schools Handbook.'' Tarook Publishing, 2004. ({{ISBN|0975687409}}) * Hovey Burgess, Judy Finelli. ''Circus Techniques.'' Brian Dube, 1989. ({{ISBN|0917643003}}) * Carrie Heller. ''Aerial Circus Training and Safety Manual.'' National Writers Press, 2004. ({{ISBN|0881001368}}) * Shana Kennedy. ''Aerial Skills Illustrated 2007.'' Project 630570 at Lulu.com, 2007. * Jayne C. Bernasconi and Nancy E. Smith. ''Aerial Dance.'' United States: Human Kinetics, 2008. ({{ISBN|0736073965}}) [https://books.google.com/books?id=yC-5S4Rt8kUC View at Google Books] * Elena Zanzu, M.A. ''Il Trapezio Oscillante: Storie di Circo nell'Aria.'' (''The Swinging Trapeze: Histories of the Circus in the Air.'') Bologna University, Italy, 2004-2005. Language: Italian.

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox fictional location |common_name=Veyshnoria |native_name={{native name|be|Вейшнорыя|italics=off}} |image_flag=Flag_of_Viejšnoryja_(Veyshnoria),_fictional_enemy_republic_for_Zapad_2017_exercise.png |image_type=Coat of arms of fictional Vajšnoryja (Veyshnoria) republic, an enemy in "Zapad-2017" exercise.jpg |symbol_type = National emblem |image=Vejsnoria location map.png |alt= |caption=Borders of the state Veyshnoria according to Zapad 2017<ref name=nn010917/> |source= |alt_name= |country= |creator= |ruler= |genre= |type=[[Fictional country]] |ethnic_group= |races= |locations=Europe |last= }} '''Veyshnoria''' ({{lang-ru|Вейшнория|translit=Veyshnoriya}}, {{lang-be|Вейшнорыя|translit=Viejšnoryja}}) is a fictional state created for [[Zapad 2017 exercise|Zapad 2017]], a joint Russo-Belarusian military training exercise. It neighbors Belarus and is an enemy of the [[Union State]]. Veyshnoria occupies most of the [[Grodno Region]] and the northwestern parts of the [[Minsk]] and [[Vitebsk]] regions.<ref name=nn010917> {{cite news | title=«Вейшнорыя», «Весбарыя» і «Лубенія» нападаюць на Беларусь і Расію — сцэнар вучэнняў «Захад-2017»|trans-title = "Veyshnoria", "Vesbaria" and "Luben" attack on Belarus and Russia - a scenario exercise" Zapad-2017 | url = http://nn.by/?c=ar&i=196541 | work= [[Nasha Niva]] | access-date = 1 September 2017 | language = be|date=29 August 2017}}</ref><ref name="BBC">{{cite news | title = Belarus at 'war' with imaginary country of Veyshnoria | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/blogs-news-from-elsewhere-41107540?SThisFB | publisher= [[BBC]] | access-date = 1 September 2017|date=31 August 2017}}</ref>
There are two other fictional enemies of the Zapad 2017 participants: Vesbaria and Lubenia.<Ref name=vbl/> Lubenia straddles the [[Suwalki gap]] and covers parts of northeastern Poland and southwestern Lithuania, while Vesbaria covers the rest of Lithuania and central Latvia.
The "proclamation" of the state caused a response on the Internet, often humorous.<ref>[https://vie.today/?language=eng Republic of Veishnoria: Official page and social network]</ref> Since September 2017, a web-based Veyshnoria have been proclaimed, which started acquiring the signs of an internet-based [[micronation]] with more than 10 thousand people signing for "citizenship"<ref>{{cite news |url= https://officelife.media/news/as-invented-the-state-has-become-a-business-project |title = Как придуманное государство стало бизнес-проектом| language = ru| trans-title= As invented the state has become a business-project|date = 8 November 2017}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news |url= https://dev.by/lenta/main/chto-zastavlyaet-belorusov-emigrirovat-v-veyshnoriyu-i-brat-s-soboy-tyurmu |title = Что заставляет белорусов эмигрировать в Вейшнорию и «брать с собой тюрьму»| language = ru| trans-title=What makes Belarusians emigrate to Veyshnoria and "take prison with them"|date = 17 February 2018}}</ref>
==Toponomy== The name "Veyshnoria" comes from the Baltic name of Veisnor (Lithuanian "Vaišnoras", Old Prussian "Waisnor") – "one who willingly treats" (hospitable).<Ref name=vbl> {{cite news | title = Вейшнорыя, Весбарыя, Лубенія: што азначаюць назвы ўмоўных ворагаў Беларусі|trans-title=Veyshnoria, Vesbaria, Lubenia: What are the names of the enemies of Belarus| url = http://nn.by/?c=ar&i=196570 | work= [[Nasha Niva]] | accessdate = 1 September 2017 | language = be|date=29 August 2017}} </ref> There are several places in Lithuania called Vaišnoriai (plural for "Vaišnoras").<ref>[[:lt:Vaišnoriai (Šiauliai)|Vaišnoriai (Šiauliai)]], [[:lt:Vaišnoriai (Joniškis)|Vaišnoriai (Joniškis)]]</ref>
==Zapad 2017 scenario== Zapad 2017 was a joint strategic military exercise of the armed forces of the [[Russian Federation]] and [[Belarus]] (the [[Union State of Russia and Belarus]]) held 14–20 September 2017, in Belarus as well as in Russia′s [[Kaliningrad Oblast]] and other north-western areas.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|title=Глава Минобороны Белоруссии: учение "Запад-2017" не направлено против третьих стран|url=http://tass.ru/opinions/interviews/4419507|agency=[[TASS]]|accessdate=1 September 2017|language=ru|trans-title=The head of the Belarusian Defense Ministry: the "Zapad-2017" doctrine is not directed against third-world countries|first=Yuri|last=Shamshur|date=17 July 2017}}</ref>
According to the scenario a conflict between "The North" (the Union State) and "The West" (a coalition of three aggressor states: Veyshnoria, Vesbaria and Lubenia) developed. "The West" tries to split the union of Belarus and Russia, worsen the socio-economic situation in the Union State, and force a change of leadership, and Veyshnoria is trying to annex parts of Belarus. After that, "the West" sends its troops enter the rest of the territory of Belarus. The Union State resists these actions.<ref> {{cite news |title=На учениях "Запад-2017" противниками России и Беларуси будут "сказочные" страны| trans-title = In the exercise "Zapad-2017" opponents of Russia and Belarus will be "fabulous" countries | url = http://hvylya.net/analytics/geopolitics/na-ucheniyah-zapad-2017-protivnikami-rossii-i-belarusi-budut-skazochnyie-stranyi.html | publisher= Hvylya| access-date = 1 September 2017 | language = ru|first=Anton|last=Shevchenko|date=8 August 2017}}</ref>
[[File:Зянон Пазьняк 1994 (заліўка).png|thumb|Paznyak's electoral map]] In a post on [[Facebook]], Belarusian economic analyst Sergey Chaly noticed a similarity between Veyshnoria and the region of Belarus where a large percentage of voters supported [[Zianon Pazniak]] in the first round of the [[Belarusian presidential election, 1994|1994 presidential election]].<ref>{{cite news | title = «Варожая Вейшнорыя» супадае з электаральнай картай Пазняка за 1994 год| trans-title="Enemy Veyshnoria" coincides with the electoral map Pozniak 1994 | url =http://nn.by/?c=ar&i=196590 | work= [[Nasha Niva]]| date= 29 August 2017 | accessdate = 1 September 2017 | language = be}}</ref> Journalist [[Leonid Bershidsky]] further pointed out that this territory has a high proportion of Catholic population and a high share of Belarusian-language speakers in the bilingual Russian-Belarusian state with dominant [[Russian Orthodox]] church. In Bershidsky's view these observations may be how the Zapad 2017 scenario was intended to be seen: Veyshnoria seeks destabilizaton of Belarus the same way, in the eyes of the Russian establishment, it happened in Ukraine (by pro-Western national forces, allegedly fomented by "[[Western world|the West]]").<ref>{{cite news | title = Belarusian Twitter users are swearing allegiance to a fictional country invented for Moscow's ‘Zapad 2017’ war-games | url =https://meduza.io/en/shapito/2017/08/31/belarusian-twitter-users-are-swearing-allegiance-to-a-fictional-country-invented-for-moscow-s-zapad-2017-war-games | publisher = [[Meduza]] | date= 31 August 2017| accessdate = 26 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Bershidsky|first1=Leonid|title=The Zapad Military Exercise Reveals Putin's Fear|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2017-09-15/the-zapad-military-exercise-reveals-putin-s-fear|website=Bloomberg|accessdate=27 September 2017|ref=bloomberg}}</ref>
==Internet reaction== The creation quickly found a humorous response in [[social media]].<ref name=vgolos>{{cite web|url=http://vgolos.com.ua/news/kraina_veyshnoriya_zavoyovuie_zhartivlyvu_populyarnist_v_sotsmerezhah_280539.html|title=Країна Вейшнорія завойовує жартівливу популярність в соцмережах|language=uk|trans-title=The country of Veyshnoria gains humorous popularity in social networks|date=2 September 2017|accessdate=2 September 2017|work=Vgolos}}</ref> On 30 August 2017, a satirical [[Twitter]] account of the Foreign Ministry of Veyshnoria appeared, which published political statements on behalf of the state.<ref name="BBC"/> According to the account, the anthem of the state is the song "Niamon" (meaning "[[Neman]]") by the Belarusian band [[Stary Olsa]]. The same account says that the official residences of the state are in [[Grodno]], the parliament and the government (in addition to the Ministry of Culture) in [[Lida]], and the [[cultural capital]] of Veyshnoria is [[Smarhon]].<ref name=vgolos/> Veyshnoria is also present on [[Facebook]],<ref name=vgolos/> and its [[Russian Wikipedia]] article had been noted as "a dry rundown of how Veyshnoria emerged" before the article was deleted and redirected to the article on Zapad 2017.<ref name="BBC"/>
Some Belarusian businessmen were quick to monetize Veyshnoria by launching a Veyshnoria website and legally registering it as a gaming service. After Belarusian President [[Alexander Lukashenko]] issued the decree which made [[cryptocurrencies]] a legal method of payment and the [[Taler (cryptocurrency)|Taler]] cryptocurrency was launched in Belarus, Taler was made the official currency of Veyshnoria. <ref name="DS">{{cite news|title=Как бы страна. Как делается бизнес на Вейшнории|url=http://www.dsnews.ua/economics/kak-by-strana-kak-delaetsya-biznes-na-nesushchestvuyushchih-gosudarstvah-05072018220000|work=Деловая столица|language = ru|date=12 July 2018}}</ref> .
===Notable Veyshnorians=== Online "Veyshnorians" were quick to notice that the following famous persons have Veyshnorian descent:<ref>[http://povin.com.ua/39575-06-09.html "МИ, НЕЗАЛЕЖНІ ВЕЙШНОРЦЫ…"] ("We, Independent Veyshnorians...") September 9, 2017 (retrieved November 28, 2017)</ref> *[[Olga Korbut]], Olympic gymnast, was born in [[Grodno]] *[[Shimon Peres]], the 9th President of Israel, was born in [[Vishnyeva]], [[Valozhyn Raion]], [[Minsk Region]], near the border with [[Lithuania]] *Parents of [[Charles Kushner]], a relative-in-law to [[Donald Trump]], were [[Holocaust survivor]]s from [[Navahrudak]] area (see [[Joseph Kushner]]).
==See also== *[[San Escobar]], another fictional country that emerged from a spontaneous internet reaction
